name: Accetti?
description:
Accetti? is a strategic card game, to win you have to make compromises with your opponents and study every round, because every move could be your last one!

Eliminate all the columns of cards you have in front of you by aligning four identical symbols before your opponents by getting rid of malus cards.

—description from the publisher (translated)
Accetti? è un gioco di carte strategico in cui per vincere bisogna scendere a compromessi con gli avversari e studiare attentamente ogni turno, perché ogni mossa potrebbe essere l'ultima!

Elimina tutte le colonne di carte davanti a te allineando quattro simboli uguali prima degli avversari sbarazzandoti delle carte malus.

—description from the publisher

name: Spingo and Whirlette
description:
The game board holds a spinner wheel in the center, two tracks numbered 1-24 on opposite sides, and two tracks numbered 0-100 by 5's on opposite sides. Those last two tracks have the numbers set in circles in one of five different colors.

The spinner wheel is divided into 24 sections. Each section contains one number 1-24, a multiple of 5 from 0-25, one of five different colors, and the word "ahead" or "back".

Four different colored wooden token are included.

—user summary

name: Spanish Fury: Nordic Fury!
description:
Nordic Fury! is a supplement for Spanish Fury!

And contains:
Two full army lists, one for the Swedes and one for the Danes, written out for the Battle! rules, but also of use for Actions! These cover most of the regiments involved, their equipment, fighting prowess, field signs, and their commanders.
Brand new cards for Battle! which will enable you to play out any engagement of the war and those produced by the Campaign game that is currently in the works! Also included is an army sheet for each army and new officer and regiment counters.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Pike and Shot, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Stock-Poker
description:
Stock-Poker combines the elements of the stock market with the gambling instinct of stock speculators. To be able to determine when to buy, sell, hold, sell short, and/or buy long is what makes or breaks stock speculators. All these factors are in the game to make Stock-Poker a fun and stimulating leisure time activity.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Elapsed Real Time Ending, Market, Roll / Spin and Move, Sudden Death Ending

name: square
description:
square consists of a rulebook and a set of 35 square plastic tiles contained in a rectangular plastic box. The game was manufactured in Austria.

The players start by taking a hand of ten tiles, at random. Each plastic tile has one of three edge shapes on each side: a square, triangular, or semicircle "cutout," or a straight edge with no cutout. The players take turns placing the square tiles on the table. Tiles are placed dominoes style, adjacent to another tile, with matching types of edges in contact.

The object of the game is to form rectangles out of the square tiles. The game ends as soon as one player runs out of tiles. Scoring is based on the number of rectangles a player formed, with points deducted for any pieces the player has remaining at the end of the game.

While a single set of the game supports play by up to three players, more can play by combining multiple sets of the game.

—user summary

name: Quadrex
description:
Quadrex is a drawless connection game for two players: Black and White. It's played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty square grid (board). The suggested board size is 19×19. The top and bottom edges of the board are colored black; the left and right edges are colored white.

A potential impasse is a 2×2 pattern of two diagonally adjacent stones of one color, one stone of the other color and an empty point. To fix a potential impasse is to place a stone of its majority color on its empty point.

Black plays first, then turns alternate. On your turn, place a stone of your color on an empty point, then fix all resulting potential impasses. If this creates further potential impasses, fix those as well, and so on.

You win if there is a chain of orthogonally connected stones of your color touching the two opposite board edges of your color. Draws are not possible.

To make the game fair, White will have the option, on their first turn only, to swap sides with Black instead of making a regular move.
mechanics: Paper-and-Pencil, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: Képis Rouges: Los Gringos

Los Gringos: is a miniatures ruleset for the Mexican-American War.

Képis Rouges is needed to play those simple rules (DBA type).
It can be played on a small size table with a limited number of minis (~80+ for the Battle of Palo Alto).

Designed for 15mm miniatures.

Sequence of play:


Movement
Defensive Fire - non active player
Mêlées


Active player follow the sequence then other player repeats it on his/her turn.

—user summary

name: Major Arcana: The Tarot Game
description:
Work out which cards to discard from other’s hands, to be the last one holding cards and win.
Players try to remember the remaining cards from numbers declared already.

The cards are based on the Major arcana of the tarot cards.

name: Gromino des oiseaux
description:
The game contains 41 cards with pictures (and 2 cards with rules). The aim of the game is to take the most possible cards to win. Cards are mixed and then equally distributed to players. The remaining cards are replaced in the box. Players pile their cards in front of them without looking at them.

The youngest player starts and places the first card of his stack visible on the table. The player sitting to his left lays a card in turn and so on. The cards placed remain on the table until one of the players can make a take.

Immediately after playing, the player carefully looks at all the cards on the table. If the card he has just placed ends a meeting (all the drawings of several cards are all on one card), he picks up all the cards of the meeting and puts them in front of him. Cards that are not part of the meeting remain on the table. Attention: if a player lays a card without realizing that he is holding a meeting, the next player has the right to pick up the cards by appropriating the take.

When no more takes are possible or when the players no longer have cards, the game is over. Everyone counts the cards he has taken and the player who took the most card wins the game.

name: Cirk
description:
Original game title - цирк (eng. - Circus).
Typical chutes ladders type board game made in Russia.
Game is based by silent film written, produced, and directed (1928) by Charlie Chaplin - The Circus.
The first player, who cross 100 stops road - wins the game.

description:
The players have to move their bird on their own five spaces long track into the nest. Movement is determined by two dice.
On the roll of 7 or more the bird may move 1 space. If two identical numbers (doubles) are rolled, the bird advances two spaces.

The first player whose bird reaches the nest wins the game.

The game continues until all birds have reached the nest.

name: Bunte Wege
description:
The players have to move their 9 (2 player game )or 7 pawns from their black starting spaces to the starting spaces of the opposite player. Movement is determined by a number die and a color die. The color die shows two colors on each side. Eeach turn only the spaces of the rolled colors may be used for movement. The first player to get all his pawns on the black destination spaces wins the game.

For the 2 player game the board remains folded and only the middle section is used for play. If more than two players play, the two outmost black spaces on each side of the middle section are not used.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: 集団陣形棋 (Shudan-Jinkeiki)
description:
集団陣形棋 (Shudan-Jinkeiki) (Troop-Chess) is an abstract game for two players, which can be played using components from other games (such as Go, Chess, Shogi). In Troop-Chess, players organize battle-formations with their pawns and use these formations in both offence and defense.

The game can be played in three versions, each using groyps of three, five or eight pawns. A player can take action only if they have organized a battle-formation using the specified number of pawns.

For this reason, a player who has reduced their pawns to fewer than the specific number, or has divided them too small, making it impossible to organize any formation, will lose the game. It is possible that both players get incapacitated at the same time, because they have reduced their pawns too much simultaneously. In this case, the game ends in draw.

Each type of battle-formation has its own nature, such as strong in attack or highly maneuverable. One formation has only mobility. As well as the predefined formations, you can create original battle-formations as you like. And modify the number of pawns that are used too.

Each pawn does not have any nature by itself, but the power or strength of the formation organized from pawns is affected by its relationship with the neighboring pieces.

What is required to determine this is only a method to judge which are allies or enemies.

Further, whilst in the original game, each pawn has no nature itself, the designer encourages players to customize the game further by introducing specialized pawns.
user summary

複数駒で陣形を築き、攻守に役立てる2人用アブストラクトゲーム。
3，5，8駒のバージョンがあり、それぞれの数で規定の陣形を作らねば行動不可能。
ゆえに、自軍の駒が既定の駒数未満に減らされるか、陣形を作れないほど分断された方の負けとなる。場合により、同数駒で双方行動不能となる場合があるが、その場合は引き分け。
陣形により攻撃力が強い、機動力が高いと性格が分かたれている。機動力のみの陣形も。
こちらが用意・提示している以外の陣形を各人が好みで創造することも可能。駒数も自由。
周囲との関係性で陣形の強さが変わるため、駒は無性格。敵味方判別の白黒があればいい。
駒は無性格であるが、発展形として特殊駒を導入するとゲームの深みは格段に増す。

name: Histo: Bijbelse helden
description:
Histo - Bijbelse Helden is a card game for 2-5 players, consisting of 35 character cards (7 sets of 5), 6 role cards and 5 action cards.

Every player receives 5 character cards and a role card. 10-15 remaining character cards are placed face-down at the table in rows of 5 cards each. Every turn a player places a card from his hand on the table and takes the card from that position in his hand. He ends his turn by turning a card in the middle over and making it visible. The players try to collect a group of 5 of the same cards that fit their role card. The first player to achieve that says "Histo" and wins the game. Other players with the same role will be awarded points as well. It's also possible to claim "Histo" when 5 of the same cards are visible in the middle, although fewer points will be awarded to the winners.

Every player receives an action card that can be played once. Players can choose from 4 different high impact actions to turn the tables in their favor. Although the mechanic is accessible and straightforward, there are a lot of different viable tactics possible to win the game.

—description from the designer

name: Reise durch Deutschland
description:
The players start in Hamburg on a round trip through Germany. The first player back in Hamburg wins the game. Movement is determined by a die. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players.

The game was published between 1933 and 1945.

name: your rope.
description:
The trick-taking game 君の縄 (your rope.) was released as part of the publisher ruri ruri games' (るりるりゲームズ) Autumn 2019 box of trick-taking games, titled トリテセット５ (Trick Taking Set 5).

In 君の縄, players will earn points by lifting an oblong cardboard object with a multi-colored rope. A player will earn more points by successfully lifting the object at more difficult points.

The cards in the game have two colored rope sections pictured in the middle, and after a hand of tricks, the player combines these sections to determine which colors of the rope the player can use to attempt to lift the object.

The player with the highest score after a number of rounds wins.

—user summary

name: Sedução
description:
The pleasure is yours. Relationship, attraction, boldness, passion, sensuality, love and shyness. Some of the most current themes that are at stake in Seduction. You and your friends will have fun discovering what each one thinks about these and many other subjects. Get ready! You will make and hear great revelations!

The game is played in teams. To get the pawn to the end of the board, players have to perform super-creative tasks, enact various kinds of situations, make sometimes funny, sometimes indiscreet guesses, and answer questions about personal topics and general affairs. All related to the art of seducing.
mechanics: Real-Time, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Arrumação
description:
In this amazing game of speed and logic you have one goal: to put the people of your team in the marked places. But beware, it's not easy to remember who's what.

You all become objects of the house. So, before calling the next occupant of the vacant seat, think about it. If you choose the wrong person your team will be harmed!

Can you think a few rounds ahead and win the match?

description: Moorings, soul mates and crystal balls! Seek knowledge with Ets and quantum Atlantic civilizations! Untangle your enemies' chakras with Horus's Positronic Board! See your opponents cards with your Scrying table! Match RPG games to the devil and fight the Sword of the Sword Spirit! Beat the Illuminatis!
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Science Fiction
mechanics: Hand Management, Player Elimination, Variable Player Powers

name: Full Captain: Tactical Naval Wargame Rules
description:
Full Captain is a Tactical Naval Wargame, designed to play actions between small groups of ships or individual ships. The game is specially designed for our 10mm Naval Range, which scale allows gamers to manoeuvre ships and fight actions using miniatures representing guns and crew members.

The Rules cover the entire “Golden Era” of sailing ships, from the mid XVII century to the first quarter of the XIX century.

Full Captain allows players to recreate the bloody boardings of the famous pirate “Black Beard”, the coastal actions of Privateers and smugglers against the Revenue authorities (His Majesty’s Customs & Revenue, Royal Navy, US Coast Guard and Revenue, French Gendarmerie, Spanish Navy, etc.), as well as small engagements between, single ships, ranging from Gunboats to big 74-gun ships of the line.

—description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, American Revolutionary War, Book, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Nautical, Pirates, Wargame

name: The East West Express Race Across Australia
description:
A simple roll-and-move race game starting in Perth on the west coast of Australia and ending in Brisbane on the east coast. Along the way delays and advances may be encountered by landing on specific numbered spots. First to reach home at Brisbane is the winner.

The graphics of biplanes on the board suggest the game dates probably post-World War 1. The Trans Australian railway linking Kalgoorlie in Western Australia across the Nullabor Plain to the eastern town of Ooldea was completed in 1917.

—user summary

name: Mostri in Mostra
description:
In this art gallery someone had a lot of fun messing with the monsters portraits. Maybe your opponent?
You must quickly try to recreate the portraits so that they will appear like the original ones.

You won't be using paint and brush to do it; instead you'll be handling coloured rolling marbles trying to place them in to the right place in the right order.

Place your frame, get the marbles ready and go! The fastest painter wins!

name: The Animal Trivia Game
description:
Not to be confused with other games with similar names. Neither the publisher nor the designer is indicated, but the game comes in an envelope saying "Enclosed: Your Free Animal Triva Game", so one might imagine that it was a promotional item or was given away for free with some product or service.
There are 30 cardboard rectangles with numbers from 1 to 30, and another 30 cardboard rectangles in 6 different groups (indicated by pictures and words): birds, insects, primates, fish, mammals, and reptiles (however, the reptile rectangles have a picture of a frog on them). One of each of these 6 groups has a stars, in addition to the pictures and the names of the groups.
The two different types of squares (numbers and animals) are put into two different containers. Players (presumably without looking) take one rectangle from each container, and this determines which question (from the question sheet) they have to answer. For example, if a player drew 6 and primates, he would have to answer the question "True or False: Lemurs and lorises have huge eyes so they can see well at night". (The correct answer here is "true"). Most correct answers give the player 5 points, but if a starred rectangle was drawn, a correct answer gives 10 points.
The game can last a chosen period of time (in which case whoever has amassed the highest total wins) or until a set target of points is reached (in which case whoever has reached that target wins).

name: Fast Play Rules for Ancient Warfare
description:
Miniatures battle game. Meant to handle large battles in a relatively brief time, although rumour has it that the "Fast Play" part is more aspiration than reality.

—user summary

name: Capsule Hole
description:
Capsule Hole (カプセルホール) has a hint of a trick-taking element to it, but for the most part players are trying to score points by having the most influence in a capsule when it's closed.

The game consists of forty tiles numbered 1-40, with the tiles being grouped in four buckets on their backs: 1-10, 11-20, 21-30, and 31-40. Players draft tiles at the start of the game while seeing only their backs; tiles in the first group have a "capsule opening" on only one edge, while tiles in the second group have a straight or curved tube from one edge to another, and tiles in the fourth group generally have three or four open edges. You can look at the faces of your tiles are you draft them.

The start player in a round plays one tile of their choice, optionally placing one of their wooden cubes on it. Each other player in turn must place one of their tiles in the same group (if possible) face down in front of them, again optionally placing one of their wooden cubes on it. Players then reveal their tiles, then add them to the shared playing area, starting with whoever has the highest-numbered tile. If you placed a cube on your tile, you then place this cube somewhere on your tile in one of the capsules.

When a capsule is closed, akin to a road being closed in Carcassonne, whichever players have the most cubes in it score points equal to the number of energy symbols in that capsule. After all the tiles have been played, whoever has the highest score wins — except that if exactly one player has scored 0 points, then they win instead!
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Closed Drafting, Tile Placement
publishers: るりるりゲームズ (ruri ruri games)

name: Deadpan
description:
Deadpan is game centered around holding your composure while abiding by hilarious rules that players draw from the deck. Players take tuns drawing one card from the deck. The object of the game is to not laugh when it is your turn to read a "Statement" card or read/answer a "Response" card all while trying to follow your own rules cards in your hand at all times.

In the deck are "Response" cards that the drawer must ask another player of their choosing, in which that player must respond, and there are "Statement" cards which the drawer must simply read out loud. What makes Deadpan unique are the hilarious rules cards that are also in the deck. When a player draws a rule card, they must abide by the rule at all times, even when it is not their turn.

The "Response" and "Statement" cards act as points. To score the "Statement" point, the drawer must successfully read the "Statement" card without laughing while following any rules in their hand. To score the "Response" card, the drawer must ask the question to another player of their choice while trying not to laugh and following their own rules. If the responding player is able to respond without laughing and follows their own rules, then they are awarded the point. If the responder fails, then the drawer who asked the question is awarded the point. If both fail, no one is awarded the point. If a player is caught not following their rules at any time, they lose one (if any) of their points. First player to collect seven points is the winner.

There are "Mannerism" - rules that implement a type of action a player must do as directed by the card, "Starters..."- implements that a player must start each sentence they speak with the statement on the card, "...Enders" - implements that a player must end each sentence they speak with the statement on the card, and "New Name" - implements that the player must refer to the directed player on the card by the name on the card anytime they address that player. There are also DEADPAN rules in the deck - These are the same categories as normal rules, but the difference being they are more over the top and the drawer gets to assign the DEADPAN rules to other players.

In the deck are also "Veto" cards and "Revenge" cards. "Veto" enables a player to discard any regular rule from anyone's hand. "Revenge" cards give the player the opportunity for payback towards any player that has given them a DEADPAN rule.

—description from the designer

name: Warr Without An Enemie: A Set of Wargaming Rules for the British Civil Wars 1639 - 1651
description:
Warr Without An Enemie is a set of wargame rules for the English Civil War developed by the Wyre Forest Gamers. The English Civil War is notable because of the large number of small actions that happened during the war. These provide a variety of interesting historical battles to fight. The player commands one to three 'brigades'. Brigades are usually 3 to 6 units, with 4 to 6 bases of figures per unit. For non historical battles brigades are generated randomly to provide interesting challenges and opportunities for the players.

A base represents 60 to 100 infantry and half that for cavalry. The players decide how many figures to use per base and base size. Units lose bases of figures, not individual figures.

The emphasis on the rules is on command and managing unit disruption caused by battlefield action. Quality of the commanders and units is usually more important than numbers or weapons. Raw units will need constant vigilance to keep them in the action while hardened Veterans will sort themselves out, dust themselves off and carry on. Commanders have different command rating and also can have individual qualities to reflect their character. A commander can thus be 'Steadfast' and good in defensive situations or a 'Drunkard' and a loose cannon. Units can receive disorder from movement, manoeuvre, combat, friendly units suffering reverses, etc. Disorder adversely effects a units abilities and after the limit is reached will lead to loses of bases. High quality units and good commander have a better ability to remove disorder.

Infantry are rated in one of 7 categories, I1 to I7. The number indicates the number of muskets and pikes within the unit. I1 means the unit is an all musket unit, while an I7 unit is all pikes. Most units are of course in between these two extremes, two muskets to one pike is an I3 unit for example. All bases fire and melee so there is no need to exactly model the ratio of weapons. When firing you need to roll your I number or higher to hit, while if in melee you need you I number or lower to hit. In this way the mix of weapons within a unit is quickly reflected. For example: An I3 unit (2 muskets to 1 pike) needs to roll 3 or higher per base to hit when firing but an I5 unit (1 musket to 1 pike) must roll 5 or higher to hit. So when firing the I3 unit will have the advantage while in a melee the reverse is the case. In a close combat the I3 unit will need to roll 3 or less to hit, while the I5 unit will need 5 or less.

There are four kinds of mainstream cavalry along with lancers and dragoons. The four kinds of cavalry allow the representation of the tactics of the period that is not possible in many other rules and is, like much of the rest of the rules, based on modern research of this fascinating period. 'Pistoleers' rely on firepower. 'Gallopers' rely on the reckless speed of their charge and the sword. While the dominant tactics of the war are the Dutch and Swedish styles of fighting. Entering combat at a high speed is an advantage but runs the risk of getting more disorder. Shooting the attackers can stop the aggressors in their tracks and leave them open to counter attack. Yet if it doesn't work.........

The aim of the game is to provide a set of rules that combine modern views of the war with an innovative and entertaining game. In the future the rules will be expanded to cover other wars and work on the Thirty Years War is well on the way.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Civil War, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Le Blockhaus
description:
Le Blockhaus easy D-day landing !

Miniature wargame rules for the 6th June 1944 US and Brits landings with 20mm (1/72) minis.
The goal is, for the Allies to capture the blockhaus as fast as possible, for the German player to delay as long as possible.
It is recommended to change sides after each game.

Sequence of play:
Post deployment the order is as follow:

Allied soldiers movements phase
Support landing crafts fire phase
German soldiers movements phase
2nd Allied movements phase
German fire phase
Allied Fire phase


Roll for reinforcement

Scale:
1 mini = 1 man
1 model = 1 vehicle
1 cm = 1 m
1 turn = 20 sec

Published in French in Vae Victis magazine.

—user summary
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Le Blockhaus 2
description:
Le Blockhaus 2 is an expansion for Le Blockhaus.

It is a miniature (20mm - 1/72) skirmish wargame rules for D-Day. It introduces an updated sequence of play as well as Hobart's Funnies and other special rules.

Sequence of play:

Post deployment the order is as follow:
Allied movement phase
Support landing crafts fire phase (1st turn only)
German movement phase
German fire phase
Allied Fire phase

Roll for Allied reinforcements from turn 3


Scale:
1 mini = 1 man
1 model = 1 vehicle
1 cm = 1 m
1 turn = 20 sec

Published in French in Vae Victis magazine.

—user summary
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Miss Dessie Dots Jolly Dollar
description:
A simple roll and move educational game teaching currency conversion from pounds/pence to decimal Australian dollars and cents. Australia changed over to decimalization in 1966.

By the roll of a dice players move along playing squares that have a money value up to 100 cents. Certain squares are red or green and when a player lands on these squares they must do a conversion from pence to cents. Correct conversion will see the player on a green square advance the cent value but on a red square go back the cent value. If the conversion is incorrect the player can go back to the start. First to reach 100 cents by exact throw is the winner.

—user summary

name: 4 billion secrets
description:
6 heroes are on a trip to the Asian continent, where 4 billion people live. Every person on that continent has their own secrets and stories to tell.
You are one of the heroes and by facing challenges and answering questions correctly within a given time you can collect badges.
The first player to gather 6 badges (2 of each category) wins the game.

name: La Petite Guerre: Skirmishing on the Frontiers of Empire – The Great War for Empire in America
description:
La Petite Guerre is a miniatures skirmish game for 18th century North America, featuring English and French regulars, colonial militias, American rebels, coureurs des bois, and Indian warbands.

In a turn, chits are drawn to determine which player gets to activate a figure, which then does all it's movement, shooting, etc. before the next chit is drawn. Not enough chits are used to allow all figures to activate, and a figure is allowed to activate twice in a turn, at the cost of the opportunity to activate another at all.

Shooting and melee are resolved by rolling dice, applying various modifiers, and looking up the result in a table. Movement allowances are similarly rolled for.

—user summary
categories: American Indian Wars, American Revolutionary War, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Come to the Fair
description:
Contained in the book Fairground Games to Make and Play by Neil and Ruth Thomson. An entirely luck-based spin and move game, but different from many such games, since every space is an intersection with 4 possible directions to another space: forwards, backwards, left, and right. The spinner (to be constructed) has these directions (F, B, L, and R) as possible results, and players must go one space in the direction they spin.
The goal is to reach the fair before other players. One is required to get an F on the spinner to begin. Some directions from spaces lead to dead ends; players who get spinner results telling them to go to a dead end must remain where they are that turn.

—user summary

name: For the Pharaoh: Wargames Rules for the Bronze and Chariot Age 3000BC-1000BC
description:
Miniatures wargames for the Bronze Age, ca 3000-1000 BC.

The ground scale is 1:1000 and the figure ratio is 1:50 for most troops, allowing fairly large battles to be fought. Note however that for chariots the ratio is only two vehicles per model, so recreating the large numbers of chariots reported in Egyptian and Assyrian sources will be a challenge!

Troops are characterized by class (regular or irregular), morale class (from A+ elites to E dregs), type (infantry, chariotry, etc.), order (close, loose, or open), armour, and weaponry.

Play is IGO-UGO, and uses written orders that need to be carried to the units to execute them by messengers.

—user summary

name: From Gilgamesh to Grant
description:
Have you ever wanted a rule system that was flexible enough to handle battles from the earliest days of recorded history? have you ever wanted a system that is capable of handling battles of truly massive sizes? Have you ever wanted a game that gave Skirmishers and light cavalry the impact and respect you always thought they were lacking in other games? Well, then the game you are looking at is the game for you.

Features:


an expansive and versatile rule set able to fight the campaigns of Gilgamesh or Grant and any in between.
simple combat resolution mechanics. now improved for speed
plays well on a standard six foot by four-foot table, reducing space needed for a large game.
Traits have been improved.
New weather effects on the battle.


—description from publisher

name: From Gilgamesh to Grant: In Those Ancient Days
description:
The first expansion for From Gilgamesh to Grant adds 23 new armies covering the period leading up to the eve of Romes ascendancy. This is not a stand-alone product it is an expansion upon the core rules found into From Gilgamesh to Grant.

—description from publisher
categories: Ancient, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Shipwreck: Scenario 01 – The battle of Latakia
description:
A ready to play scenario based on the battle of Latakia, the first ever guided missile engagement in modern naval warfare.

Designed for use with SHIPWRECK, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


A description of the action, results and long-term consequences.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved.



Instructions to set up the scenario, starting positions, victory conditions, variation rules, and



a solo play option.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Idaho-opoly
description: Monopoly with an Idaho flavor. Buy your favorite Idaho properties, increase your rent by collecting Small Towns and trading them in for Big Cities. Add in some snowfall, mountain biking, and a three day epic lift ticket and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun!
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game – Ice and Fire Draft Pack
description:
Ice & Fire draft products for A Game of Thrones: The Card Game introduce a new draft format for the game. Players jointly build their decks in real time from a shared pool of random cards, then test their mettle against each other using these newly-built decks.

At the heart of this alternative format are randomized Ice & Fire Draft Packs. Compiled according to a custom algorithm, and drawn from a pool of 240 pre-selected A Game of Thrones: The Card Game cards, each Draft Pack introduces a unique combination of 50 draft cards. Draft Packs are printed and made available to you via Fantasy Flight Games in-house manufacturing.

Each player in an Ice & Fire draft will need two separate packs:
1) One fixed, reusable Ice & Fire Draft Starter pack – rules and 19 essential cards that provide a foundation for your deck
2) One Ice & Fire Draft pack – a selection of 50 randomized cards to be drafted

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval, Negotiation, Novel-based
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Combat Team Command: Wargame Rules for Cold War and Modern Combined Arms Combat
description:
Combat Team Command is a set of miniature wargame rules that allow players to take on the role of a battlegroup commander in charge of a combined arms force using small scale miniatures such as 1/300, 1/285, 10mm or 15mm.

The rules provided in this book deal primarily with the cold war period, notably a hypothetical third world war during the 1980s. The rules can be used to fight earlier or later conflicts. Army lists for the following conflicts are included


1980s Cold War Gone Hot
Arab Israeli Wars
1991 Gulf War


The key focus of these rules is on the effective command and control or a player’s force. It is vital for players to correctly assign orders to the formations and units under the command of their officers to keep them fighting effectively.

The rules also use a card driven activation system that successfully creates a "fog of war" and keeps both players busy all the time.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Cavalier: Miniature Wargame Rules for the Age of Pike & Shot
description:
Cavalier is a set of miniature wargame rules for fighting large skirmishes from the age of pike and shot covering the period from the mid 16th century to the late 17th century.

The rules can be used to play battles from any of the many conflicts of this war-torn period such as the Italian Wars, the Thirty Years War and the English Civil Wars.

The game has been designed with 28mm miniatures in mind however there is the flexibility to use any scale with any system of basing. Games will usually involve small forces of 30 to 100 men or horse and can be played in a few hours.

Standardised stats are included for unit types of the period giving players the flexibility to build any unit they wish be it fictional or historical.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Battleship Command: WWII Naval Wargame Rules
description:
The game of Battleship Command allows players to take on the role of Second World war admirals commanding squadrons and fleets in the many theatres of the war at sea.

The rules are designed for players to command fleets of one to 10 ships however larger actions can be fought if players wish. The rules are intended to be fast to play allowing an action to be fought to a conclusion within a few hours of play.

Battleship Command also includes a new command and control system where the quality of the officers under your command can have a major impact on the game.

The rulebook includes all the rules needed to play, generic and historical scenarios as well as ship and aircraft data for the British Royal Navy, the Kriegsmarine, French Navy, Regia Marina, US Navy and the Imperial Japanese Navy.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame, World War II

name: Rise of the Battleships: Pre-dreadnought Naval Wargame Rules
description:
Rise of the Battleships is a set of naval wargame rules covering the later ironclad and pre-dreadnought era of naval warfare including the period from the 1870s to 1905.

The rules are primarily designed for small fleet actions with up to 10 ships per side however rules are included to play battles with much larger fleets.

—description from the publisher

name: Target Locked-On: Modern Air Combat Wargame Rules
description:
Target Locked On! is a set of miniature wargame rules designed to play air combat engagements from the cold war, modern day or near future with jet aircraft. The rules are designed to be simple, fast and most importantly fun to play.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Book, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: Hide-and-Seek with the Bruin Boys
description:
Contained in the Jack and Jill Book of Games and Puzzles 1969 (pp. 20-21), which has a 1968 copyright. A luck-based roll and move game, but with a couple differences from most such games:

1) Most of the spaces, which make up an horizontal figure 8, have an arrow on them (all pointing forwards); the intersection space has two arrows. Players may choose to start on any of these spaces.

2) The goal of the game is not to reach the end of the track (as there is no end), but rather to be the first one to land on all of the 8 spaces which have pictures of one of the Bruin Boys on them.

name: Shipwreck: Scenario 02 – Operation Praying Mantis
description:
Operation Praying Mantis is a ready to play scenario based on Operation Praying Mantis, the first ever guided missile engagement fought by the US Navy.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile, with a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


A description of the action, results and long-term consequences.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, instructions to set up the scenario, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shipwreck: Scenario 03 – the Bubiyan Turkey-Shoot
description:
The Bubiyan Turkey-Shoot is a ready to play scenario based on operations against an Iraqi amphibious assault in the 1990-91 Gulf War.

Designed for use with SHIPWRECK, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


A description of the action and results.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions, variants and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 01: The Assault on South Georgia
description:
Corporate Rosario 01 - the assault on South Georgia is the first in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


A description of the action and results.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions. Variants include fighting the engagement as if the war was fought in 1972, 1992, 2002 or 2012!


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 02: the Empire strikes back
description:
Corporate Rosario 02 - the Empire strikes back

is the second in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

The British task force closes in and begins to bombard the Argentine defences.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


A description of the action and results.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 03: The Three Musketeers
description:
Corporate Rosario 03 - the Three Musketeers is the third in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A small British squadron runs the gauntlet of mines, fast attack craft, submarines and aircraft to dash in and conduct a surface bombardment.

Designed for SOLO play, but can be used for two or more players.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


A description of the action and results.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 04: Breaking the Pincer
description:
Corporate Rosario 04 - breaking the pincer is the fourth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A British submarine hunts a small Argentine squadron. A scenario based on the sinking of the old Argentine cruiser General Belgrano.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


A description of the action and results.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 05: Enter the Ring
description:
Corporate Rosario 05 - Enter the ring is the Fifth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

This is the big one! The closest that the two sides came to a major fleet action, in real life frustrated by poor weather. This illustrates what could have happened, as Argentine task forces move on the British task force.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


A description of the action and results.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 06: Rolling Back the Pickets
description:
Corporate Rosario 06 - Rolling back the pickets Sixth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the May 4th 1982 attack that sank the British Destroyer HMS Sheffield, the first use of the devestating exocet anti-ship missile.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems too.

Includes:


A description of the action and results.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.



Optional variations to refight the action in 1972 and 1992


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 07: Encounters in the Sound
description:
Corporate Rosario 07 - Encounters in the Sound is the seventh in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the transit of the British frigate HMS Alacrity through the narrow Fallkland Sound, braving mines, shore batteries, fast attack craft and submarines, and all with a time limit! For two players, but suitable for solo play too.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:


A description of the action and results.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


Optional variations to refight the action in 1972, 1992 and 2002!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 08: Operation Sutton
description:
Corporate Rosario 08 - Operation Sutton is the eighth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the opening day of "Operation Sutton", the British landing on the Falkland Islands. Can they repulse wave after wave of Jet fighter-bombers?

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:


A description of the action and results.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 09: Bomb Alley
description:
Corporate Rosario 09 - Bomb Alley is the ninth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the thrid day of "Operation Sutton", the British landing on the Falkland Islands. The initial flurry of knee-jerk air attacks is over. Both sides have had a chance to evaluate and alter their tactics. Who has done the better job?

Designed for use with SHIPWRECK, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:


A description of the action and results.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: 電力会社対助役 (Power Co. vs Mayor)
description:
The game 電力会社対助役 (Power Co. vs Mayor) is a postcard game pitting one player representing the power company against the other player who takes on the roll of the mayor.

Players must supply their own components: 1 six-sided dice, 4 cubes, and components to use as money. The game takes place over 4 rounds, each consisting of three phases.

In each of the rounds, the mayor and the power company representative will each have a chance to roll the die, hiding the value, and state a number. Depending upon the other player's choice, one player collects money and the other adjusts the cubes that represent the income of the power plants. Afterwards, the power company collects income.

The postcard shows 4 power plants. In the first round, the player only collects income from the first plant. In the second round, the player collects income from the first and second plant, etc.

The player with the most money after 4 rounds wins.

name: Shipwreck: Submarines!
description:
Submarines! is a set of ship detail sheets for Submarines, for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile.


128 pages,
120 visual representation of different submarine classes from 25 nations.


A great boon to your Shipwreck gaming!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hidden Movement, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 10 - The National day attack
description:
Corporate Rosario 10 - The National day attack is the tenth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the attack upon the 42/22 picket combination of HMS Coventry and HMS Broadsword. Variations include the action refought in 1972, 1992, 2002 and 2012.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:

A description of the action and results.

Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 11: Bluff Cove disaster
description:
Corporate Rosario 11 - Bluff Cove disaster is the eleventh in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the attack on British landing ships at Bluff Cove, the greatest single loss of life for the British in the Falklands war. Variations include the action refought in 1972, 1992 and 2002.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:


A description of the action and results.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 12: Exocet vs Carriers
description:
Corporate Rosario 12 - Exocet vs Carriers is the twelfth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the last air-launched exocet attack on the British carriers. One last attempt by Argentina for victory at sea.

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:


A description of the action and results.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions.


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shipwreck: Corporate Rosario – Number 13: The Last Missiles
description:
Corporate Rosario 13 - The last missiles is the thirteenth in a series of ready to play scenarios based on the Falklands War of 1982.

A scenario based on the last serious air attack on the British carriers. Using tankers the Argentines got their aircraft into a flank position. Can surprise make up for lack of numbers and technology?

Designed for use with Shipwreck, Vandering Publications d10 based wargames rules system for naval warfare in the age of the guided missile. With a little modification could be used for other rules systems.

Includes:


A description of the action and results.



Ship detail sheets for all units involved, starting map, starting positions and victory conditions. Variations for refighting the action in 1972 and 2012!


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Muskets & Shakos: The Napoleonic Wars 1803-1815
description:
Muskets and Shakos is a unit based game where units are composed of 2 to 20 figures. In Muskets and Shakos you can choose from two sides, with a total of seven factions. In Muskets and Shakos you can command a division of troops, chosen from the following list:

French (including French satellites).
Austrian.
British (often including allied troops such as the Portuguese.
Prussian.
Russian.
Spanish.
Turks (both the forces of the Sultan and the Mamelukes).

Whichever you choose you must lead your men through the war, the Napoleonic War, fighting when needed because it’s all about victory and glory, and in some cases, just survival!

Muskets and Shakos shares game mechanics with our popular French & Indian War rules set, Muskets and Mohawks. If you already have Mohawks you have a leg up on learning Shakos, but if you don’t, no need to worry. We’ve broken the rules down into smaller pieces with examples and small exercises to make learning the game a snap.

name: "This War Without An Enemy": English Civil War Battlefield Rules & County-Based Campaign System
description:
This War Without an Enemy - English Civil War Battlefield Rules & County-Based Campaign System

The English Civil War when gamed at County level gives great opportunities for gaming this fascinating period. You have the problem of controlling areas for your cause, denying them to your enemy and yet always at the whim of the King or Parliament in providing the great central field armies with resources. The great National events of the great battles or the support of the Scots or the arrival of the great central field armies as they maraud through your county makes for a most unpredictable game.

The novel battlefield rules emphasise the limitations of command and allow the games to flow fast and furious such that they are often over in a couple of hours or the time they would have been fought in reality.

Scope: Included are a set of battlefield figure rules for fighting battles up to 6,000- 8,000 men with a full colour Campaign system to fight the war. Thus your battles will have a context of when and why they were fought. There is also a system for fighting one-off battles.

Contents: 56 page Gamebook, 2 x A4 Unit Counters, 1 x A4 Game Counters, A4 sheet of Fate cards Campaign Calendar, 2 x A4 Off-Table Charts, There is a two-page Playsheet (one for the Campaign System one for the Battlefield) and 2 A3 or 4 A4 map of Worcestershire.

Scales


Ground Scale: 1” = 10 yards/metres. All combat and movement are by handspan or 6” rules. So a battle is approx. half a mile by a third of a mile



Time Scale: 1 Turn = 10-15 minutes



Table Size: 6 x 4 ft. up to 8 x 6 ft.



Figure/Base ratio: Figures per base according to pocket. We use Pendraken’s 10 mm figures with 12 pike, 8 shot, 4 cavalry or 1 gun and 2-4 crew per base. 1 Base = 50 foot or 25 horse. Ratio is approx. 1:6 to 1:10.


—description from publisher
categories: Book, Civil War, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Ti non es de aquí? Xúnior
description:
Ti non es de aquí? Xúnior is a board game in which players must demonstrate their knowledge of Galiza and other general culture topics, answering the questions that arise in the game, divided into 4 blocks or thematic areas:


language
sciences, geography, resources
history, heritage, traditions, personalities
general culture, present


The first three categories are specific to our country. The game combines questions with mini-challenges that will test players in skills such as drawing or mime.

—description from the publisher

name: Ragamuffins
description:
Ragamuffins is a city building game in which the players take on the role of Old World capitalists who employ street urchins to thieve from fruit markets in an effort to manipulate prices.

The game is played across 16 rounds, on a modular city map of 64 squares. At the beginning of each round 5 ships are loaded with 2 fruit tiles, and set sail for 4 ports within the city. Normally, on a player's turn they'll dock one of the available ships at an open port, and unload a fruit tile into that section of the city, thereby establishing a market. The remaining fruit tile is added to the player's stockpile. Each player controls a gang of 6 ragamuffins, of which only 4 will be deployed within the city each game. These ragamuffins are tasked with stealing from specific markets. These targets are hidden from the other players. At the end of the game, the player who manages to increase the demand for their stockpile the most, via robbing the various markets in the city, is the winner.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Commodity Speculation, Modular Board, Pattern Building, Secret Unit Deployment, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Tile Placement, Variable Set-up

name: By Their Fruits You Will Know Them
description:
As never before you will have the opportunity to learn the Word of God in a unique and entertaining way. The goal of the game is for players to fill (or empty) their fruit trees (scorecard) to advance to the next level. The player who correctly answers the multiple choice questions, riddles, true and false statements, and wildcards, will win fruit for the tree. The first player to advance through the two levels and reach the arms of Jesus, is the winner!

—description from the back of the box

name: "Paris the City of Light": Wars of Empire IV – The Republican Phase of the Franco-Prussian War of 1870-71 Battlefield Rules & Campaign System
description:
Paris City of Light- Wargame and Campaign Rules for the Republican Phase of the Franco-Prussian War. It is the fourth entry in the Wars of Empire series.

Following the defeat of the French regular army in the frontier battles, the surrounding of Marshal Bazaine in Metz and the defeat and capture of Napoleon III at Sedan the war was expected to end. Instead The French Empire was overthrown and a new Republic created to carry on the war.

With astounding speed new French armies were formed to continue the war using remnants of the old army, the garde mobiles and depot companies not overrun by the Germans. With these they attempted to harass and defeat the Germans besieging Paris. The Germans were themselves tied down in the siege of Metz and Paris and thus only had a small number of forces to hold back the French. It was to be a close run thing.....

Scope: Included are a set of corps and army level figure rules with a full colour Campaign system to fight the war. Thus your battles will have a context of when and why they were fought. There is also a system for fighting one-off battles.

Game Aids: 67 pages gamebook of the history, campaign and battlefield rules, 2 pages of game and unit counters, 2 pages of French and Germans orders of battle, page of Campaign Action Cards, Campaign Calendar, Off map display for sieges of Paris and Metz, 2 Page Playsheet, Battlefield options cards, 3 pages of battlefield Fate Cards, 2 page Line of March Cards and 4 x A4 or 2 x A3 Colour Campaign Maps.

Scales


Ground Scale: 1” = 100 metres. All combat and movement are by 10” squares or 1 km. So a battle is approx. 7 km x 5 kms
Time Scale: 1 Turn = 20-30 minutes
Table Size: 6 x 4 ft. up to 12 x 6 ft.
Figure/Base ratio: Figures per base according to pocket. We use 10 mm figures with 4 infantry, 3 cavalry or 1 gun and 3 crew per base. With 3 - 4 Bases per Infantry Battalion or Cavalry Regiment. Ratio is approx. 1:40 to 1:60


—description from the publisher

name: "Trapped Like a Fox": Wars of Empire III – The Seven Weeks' War of 1866 Battlefield Rules & Campaign System
description:
Trapped like a Fox, Campaign & Wargame Rules for The Seven Weeks War of 1866 is the third opus in the Wars of Empire series.

The game covers the Austro-Prussian War including the West German and Italian theatres. The onus is on the Prussian’s and their allies to advance against the Austrian allies in West Germany as well as cross into Bohemia and seek a decisive victory.

Depending on the campaign results the Diplomatic Chart will influence the political stance of Britain, Russia, France and Denmark. It can also affect the deployment of Prussian Landwehr, and a possible local armistice in the German States or Italy. Thus you cannot ignore the political dimension of the conflict. The campaign will therefore result in a number of battles with a context.

Game Aids: Included is

a 65 page Gamebook with a short history, campaign and battlefield rules.
There is also a system for fighting one-off battles.
There are three campaign maps,
2 pages of game counters,
2 pages of orders of battle,
Campaign Calendar,
Diplomatic Display Chart.


For the battlefield rules there is

a Battlefield Design Sheet,
Orders of March,
Fate Cards,
Battlefield Turn Options and
2 page Playsheet.


—description from the publisher

name: Draft Beer
description:
You've finally fulfilled your lifelong dream, to open a bar! But when you go to tell your friends, you discover they have also opened bars, in the same town even! So in the spirit of good natured rivalry, you'll stock your bars with the best beer and attract the town's best customers. May the best bar win!

Draft Beer is a pick and pass drafting game for 2-6 players, taking approximately 20 minutes to play. There are three rounds where you draft 8 cards, and at the end of each round you will use those cards to attract customers from the town to your bar to score points. The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

The cards are double-sided with the front having beers and food that you draft, while the back has the various customers in the town. Each round, players are dealt 8 cards to draft, and 5/6/7 customers will be dealt into the "town" (depending on round). Beer cards have 3 symbols, representing qualities: color, price and taste. These qualities each have 3 possibilities; light, dark, cheap, malty, etc... Customer cards have a point value, and one or two qualities they are looking for. So they may want cheap, light beers, or maybe dark expensive beers. After all the cards have been drafted, players will reveal their bar's selection, then go through the customers one by one to determine which bar they go to. The player whose bar has the most symbols they want is where they will go, and on a tie they will patronize both bars equally (awarding VP chits to all tied players). Customers are kept until the end of the game for scoring.

Additionally, there are two other kinds of cards: salty snacks and bar food. These can attract customers, and are kept between rounds to score you points at the end of the game. The players with the most of each will get points.

Once all three rounds have completed, the player with the most points has the most successful bar and is the winner!

—description from the designer

name: TOP the LOT
description:
TOP the LOT is a simple children's game for 2 players. The game consists of 1 die, discs on 2 colors (red and blue) and a miniboard.
The aim of the game is for one player to top the 3 towers of discs with his color.
On each turn a player throw the dice and must move that number of discs to an adjacent tower.
Player must move the full score of the dice and passing is not allowed.

—user summary

name: Durch die Kolonien
description:
Durch die Kolonien. Aus der neuen kuenstlerischen Serie "Spiele zur Lebenskunde" (Eng. Through the Colonies. From the new artistic series "Games for Life Science").
It is typical vintage roll and move game.
The player, who cross the route with 125 stops first, wins the game.

Content (not sure if it is a complete game list):
6 x number cards 1-6
47 x red cards
49 x blue cards
6 x tin figures
2 x dice
1 x bowl
1 x cloth bag
23 x coins
1 x game board

—user summary

name: The Peter Pumpkin Home Safe Game
description:
A presumably free Canadian game teaching children about how to be safe when trick or treating on Halloween; it consists of simply a sheet of paper (the reverse side has some "Halloween Safety Tips" and a picture to color). It is bilingual in English and French (the French title is Le jeu de securite de Claude la Citrouille). No year of publication, publisher, or designer is given.
An entirely luck-based roll and move game using 1 die. The board has 23 spaces; the player who reaches the last space first wins. Some spaces have instructions directing players to go back or forwards, e.g. "Went inside strange house GO BACK 3 SPACES".

—user summary

name: 修道院はどこに消えた？ (Where did the monastery disappear?)
description:
修道院はどこに消えた？ (Shuudouin wa Dokoni Kieta?) (Where did the monastery disappear?) is a co-operative mystery game. It has the charm of thinking and discussion and does not have a concealment element. Can you find the lost monastery tile within 30 minutes of the time limit?
publisher's summary

"Where did the monastery disappear?" is a co-operative mystery game (including solitaire play). Like other murder mystery games, deduction and discussion are the core elements of this game, but there's no hidden identity mechanism as there's no crime or suspect.

Story:
Five gamers gathered at a convention and played several games. When the convention was about to end, they found a monastery tile was missing from Carcassonne they brought. They have to find out where it's gone.

Each of five players is assigned one character and six clue cards which are specific to the character. No player is allowed to look at the face of clue cards at the beginning of the game.

During the game, players may reveal any clue cards upon all players' agreement. Based on the clues revealed, players discuss the situation and determine their answer.

The game ends when 30 minutes has passed. They reveal the answer card and check if their answer was correct. If correct, they win the game and they are awarded a detective title depending on how few clue cards they revealed.
user summary
publishers: Mysboard Games (ミスボドゲームズ)

name: シンシュキョウギ (Shinshu-Kyogi)
description:
シンシュキョウギ (Shinshu-Kyogi) is a Japanese card game. Each player, as a spokesman of a fictitious sport at a serious press conference, tries to announce the absurd name of a new sport game without laughing.

プレイヤーは、架空のスポーツの発表記者会見の発表者となり、笑ってはいけない厳粛な場で、とんでもない新種競技を間違えずに発表するゲーム。
publisher's summary
categories: Card Game, Humor, Memory, Party Game, Sports

name: パンツはどこへ消えた？ (Who Moved My Under Pants?)
description:
パンツはどこへ消えた？ (Who Moved My Under Pants?) is a Japanese chasing game.

You are junior school children, waiting for your teacher to visit and inspect your home. You are getting dressed, but the cat has taken your underpants! Where are they? If the teacher catches you with a bare bum, you will get extra homework!

Players use cards to move around the rooms in their house and the garden, trying to catch the cat, which has their underwear on its head. If a player can catch the cat, they flip the token to show their pants. But now the siblings can also try to get back. The teacher advances along a track until it reaches the house.

(The publisher notes that there is some errata on a few cards in the first edition).
mechanics: Hand Management, Sudden Death Ending, Track Movement
publishers: Narumi Factory (鳴海製作所娯楽部)

name: Donald Duck Universal Travel Game
description:
The Donald Duck Universal Travel Game was produced by Nintendo under licence from Walt Disney studios in the early 1960s.

This futuristic space themed game sees players follow a path through the cosmos moving by the number determined by a spinner. Certain spaces on the playing board will help or hinder progress. Players move to a launch pad on a space station and flick their playing disk towards a target, similar to the other Disney game, Tomorrowland Rocket to the Moon. The playing piece closest to the middle of the target receives the most points and that player wins the game.

—user summary

name: 羅生門 (Rashomon)
description:
羅生門 (Rashomon) is a Japanese card game, based upon the short story Rashōmon by Ryunosuke Akutagawa.

Set in the ruined capital of the Heian era, the player becomes an old woman, and in the Rashomon gateway, makes a wig by tearing the corpse's hair while screaming, avoiding capture and strangers. The game reflects the story's discussion of the morality of resorting to criminal acts in order to survive.

(Note, the Kurosawa film is actually based on a separate story by Ryunosuke Akutagawa, 'In A Grove'.)
user summary

name: 尼寺へ行け！ (Amadera e ike!)
description:
尼寺へ行け！ (Amadera e ike! or Get thee to a nunnery!) is a Japanese card game, based upon the play Hamlet, by William Shakespeare. In the play, the famous phrase 'Get thee to a nunnery' is declared. The game copies this as players challenge each other with Shakespearean insults, trying to drive the other players insane.
user summary

name: NucleAnts
description:
THE ANT IS NEAR!

NucleAnts is a fast paced, middleweight game about ants that survived the nuclear apocalypse. Mankind has finally failed. Inside humanity's contaminated ruins, gigantic nucleant queens now reign over their countless brood. Newborn ants mutate to serve as hunters, guardians, gatherers and many more. Which colony will evolve?

Roll and combine your genetic dice. Place them on your chosen mutation-cards to use their effects! Get more dice! Destroy your rivals! Gather precious atomic waste! But be fast, other players may preempt you. And be aware of the dangerous DoomDie: its risky powers produce boon ore bane for your brood. Claim the most precious atomic waste to become the all powerful ant empress and win the game.

—description from the publisher
categories: Animals, Dice, Fantasy, Horror, Science Fiction
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Re-rolling and Locking, Simultaneous Action Selection, Victory Points as a Resource, Worker Placement with Dice Workers

name: Schnappschuss
description:
Schnappschuss is composed by 36 card board tiles. Each tile is composed by 4 parts of a Swiss photography (landscape, tourist attraction, typical Swiss motives). The corners of 4 tiles, correctly arranged, make a complete picture. All tiles are evenly distributed. On his turn, a player may add one or more tiles on the table, if he enlarges a picture correctly. The player who first run out of tiles wins.

—user summary

name: マンドリンオーケストラ！ (Mandolin Orchestra!)
description:
マンドリンオーケストラ！ (Mandolin Orchestra!) is a Japanese card game. The game was produced in a limited edition of ten copies, sold at the Tokyo Game Market December 2016.

Mandolin Orchestra! is for 4 players only. Each player is trying to assemble a full mandolin orchestra, needing six instruments (first and second mandolin, mandola, mandocello, guitar, and double bass). The cards show the instrument, a value, and a colour, according to the type of song that musician prefers.

The game is driven by a deck of event cards. Another set of song cards tells the players what instruments and values are required to perform the song.

Players can draft cards when they match their colour, and by trading with other players, they can get their orchestra together. Once a player can match a song card, they declare and the music begins.
mechanics: Hand Management, Negotiation, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: 米光と抜群のゲームデザイナーズ (Yonemitsu to batsugun no gēmudezaināzu)

name: INTERVIEW
description:
INTERVIEW is a Japanese deduction game. Players take part in an interview process, using a set of cards. The game has over 40 question cards, plus role cards, and scenario cards.

Players become narrators and answer questions in order. However, only one person is telling the truth. Players must determine who is the truthful player.

The designer was seeking to generate the same excitement and brain chemistry people experience in serious interviews. Being forced to answer questions produces new ideas later.

The game was hand made by the designer in time for the Tokyo Game Market in December 2016.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Party Game
publishers: 米光と抜群のゲームデザイナーズ (Yonemitsu to batsugun no gēmudezaināzu)

name: The Quest for the Golden Goblet
description:
Contained in the Robin of Sherwood Annual 1986 (but the copyright is 1984). A simple roll and move game, but the two players go on different tracks, both of which lead to the golden goblet -- the player who arrives at it first wins. Two dice are used and one must roll doubles to begin moving. Both tracks have spaces with instructions to lose a turn or to move forward 2 or 3 spaces.

—user summary

name: Napoleonic Game of War
description:
Napoleonic GAME OF WAR wargame rules are the second in the series following on from our 18th century set.

They are also designed for 25mm or 28mm scale figures, with 16-24 figures per infantry battalion, 4-6 figures per cavalry squadron, and artillery units of one model cannon and up to 4 gunners.

They are intended to be in the ‘old school’ stream of wargaming popularised by the likes of Donald Featherstone and Terry Wise - which means lots of dice throwing and gentlemanly conduct on the part of the players while bringing out the subtle tactics of this period of history!
Units have variable motivation and training, straggler losses happen due to disruption during battle (which is recoverable by dressing ranks), nuances in both artillery and small arms development are represented, and besides that you can have units lie down, set buildings on fire, read a treatise on rates of fire in the rules, use optional rules for sickness and supply, and employ the rules for weather, decoys, and unit characterisation - I say, what more could a budding general want!

This set covers the period 1789-1815, including the European Revolutionary Wars and bring in period flavour tweaks, so we have attacks in column of division, clouds of skirmishers, more badly trained troops(!), as well as gallant cavalry charges! National variations are covered as well.

—description from the publisher

name: Vive le Roi!: Fast Play 18th Century Wargame Rules for the Wars of Frederick the Great, Malborough
description:
Vive le Roi! is a set of fast play 18th century grand tactical wargame rules bringing out the differences in drill and the like throughout the century.
The first half of the rules are the game mechanisms, with details on basing units and creating a wargames army in the second half (since during play it is useful to have the rules at the front!).

Each infantry battalion, cavalry squadron, and artillery battery is represented by a single stand with armies organised into brigades, wings and having a baggage trayne. National differences are covered.

The game sequence is basically of the You go – I go type.

Rule sections are as follows:


Sequence of Play
Infantry Movement
Cavalry Movement
Artillery, baggage, and generals movement
Moving through other bases
Cannonades
Overhead fire
Howizters and mortars
Shrinkage, disorder, confusion and routing.
Combat and musketry
Close combat
Pursuit
Morale
Generals
Dragoons
Command and control
Disintegration
Basing your army
Army organisation
Army ratios
Troop quality
Cuirasses
Lances and eastern cavalry
Campaigns
Lack of supply
Soft ground
Deploying for battle
The pyromaniac bit…


—description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Pequot War: Scenario Book for Song of Drums and Tomahawks
description:
Pequot War Scenario Book:

Wargame Scenarios Retelling the story of the Pequot War in New England, July 1636 to September 1638

Refight the Pequot War in 12 Scenarios!


Scenarios with maps, orders of battle, special rules, and victory points
Narrative retelling of the History by stages of the war through scenario introductions
New or modified Traits to Song of Drums and Tomahawks for this war
More detailed treatment and rules for early blackpowder weapons
Map charting the location of battles of the Pequot War
Campaign rules for two sides to refight the war and determine victory


—description from the publisher
categories: American Indian Wars, Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Rijm memory
description:
The Dutch game Rijm memory (Rhyme Memory) is a game consisting of 36 cardboard cards.
Instead of normal memory, the cards don't show the same image twice, but the names of the items shown on them rhyme.

name: "Home Before the Leaves Fall": The Opening Campaign on the Western Front in 1914 – Battlefield Rules & Campaign System
description:
Home Before the Leaves Fall - 1914 Western Front Campaign and Battle System

The game covers the opening campaign of the Great War in the West with the Germans carrying out the Schlieffen Plan and the French their Plan XVII. There are rules and counters for a map campaign but the heart of the system are the novel tabletop rules to fight either corps on corps or multi-corps battles in a few hours where the campaign will give context for the battle created by the campaign manoeuvrings.

We have also included a mini-campaign system where results from the previous corps on corps fight leads to later fights with ever more exhausted forces.

Scales


Ground Scale: 10” = 2.5 km 100 metres. Movement is by width or length of the Playsheet. Artillery ranges are 2 or 3 lengths of the Playsheet so there is lots of space for manoeuvring into position and deciding the line of advance.



Time Scale: 1 Turn = 1 hour
