name: Ostfront: Fall Weiss – September 1939 - September 1940
description:
Fall Weiss is the 1939 / 1940 supplement for Ostfront, that has been a year in the making. Covering the Invasion of Poland, the Battle of France and the forces involved. Fall Weiss includes complete army lists for the Polish Armed Forces, French Army, and lists for the early Wehrmacht, Soviet, and British Armies.

Fall Weiss contains:

a full campaign complete with map,
3 brand new scenarios - 1 depicting Dunkirk, and another for Westerplatte,
as well as the extensive army lists, history and descriptions of each unit.
Fall Weiss adds over 50 new units!


Ever wanted to field a Panzer III Ausf. A with 15mm of armor? Or perhaps a legion of 7TP Polish light tanks? Perhaps the BT-2 or BT-5 cavalry tanks are more your style? or perhaps the endless variants of British Cruiser tanks? From the Mk I all the way through to the Mk V, even including the Mk IIA CS version with the 94mm gun! Hell, you could even throw in a Daimler Dingo while you're at it! And don't forget the wz. 34 armored car...

All the French tanks and arms are covered, from the Hotchkiss H35 cavalry tank, to the Char D1, Char 2C, and Char B1 bis, and of course the ubiquitous Renault FT.

The field guns of the opening period are covered, from the short barrel infantry support guns like the LeIG 18 to the 76mm Soviet regimental gun. larger calibers include the Polish Wz.36 (a copy of the Bofors 37mm), the German 5cm PaK 36, British 2-pdr, and the French 75mm M1897 and 47mm APX field guns.

Cavalry are of course covered, with universal cavalry units available.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Ostfront: Quick-Fire Rules
description:
Ostfront: Quick-Fire Rules

These rules will give you everything needed to play Ostfront, from the basic rules, to the Army lists.

Meant as an introduction to the rule set, this is a simplified version of the rules, with basic army lists for Wehrmacht, Soviet, U.S. and British forces.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Ostfront: Royal Italian Army List
description:
Royal Italian Army List

This book covers the vehicles and forces of the Royal Italian Army in World War 2. From the Lince Scout Car to the Ubiquitous M14/41 Carro Armato, from the Autoblinda armored car, to the Autocannone flak cannon mounted on a Lancia truck.

The Royal Italian Army List covers the 3 main period of the war; early, mid and late, and covers the evolution of the units over that time. It covers artillery, air support and defense, various light vehicles, 3 types of infantry, and the many tanks available to the Royal Italian Army during the war.
This Book has a detailed description of each unit, describing their abilities and special rules, as well as quick reference tables at the back, covering the various weapons and units available at a glance, and perfect for building army lists from, or for checking stats during play.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Ostfront: United States Armed Forces
description:
United States Armed Forces List

This book covers the vehicles and forces of the United States in World War 2. From the basic infantryman, to the mighty Pershing Tank, from the M8 Greyhound armored car to the T34 Calliope rocket-launching Sherman variant. Every unit a U.S. commander could want is covered, allowing for a wide range of forces to be built.

The United States Armed Forces list covers the 3 main period of the war; early, mid and late, and covers the evolution of the units over that time. It covers artillery, air support and defense, various light vehicles, 3 types of infantry, and the many tanks available to the United States during the war.

This Book has a detailed description of each unit, describing their abilities and special rules, as well as quick reference tables at the back, covering the various weapons and units available at a glance, and perfect for building army lists from, or for checking stats during play.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Ostfront: British Army List
description:
British Army List

This book covers the vehicles and forces of the British Army in World War 2. From the humble Bren Carrier to the mighty Churchill, from the Archer Tank Destroyer to the Matilda Hedgehog. Every unit a British commander could want is covered, allowing for a wide range of forces to be built.

The British Army List covers the 3 main periods of the war; early, mid and late, and covers the evolution of the units over that time. It covers artillery, air support and defense, various light vehicles, 3 types of infantry, and the many tanks available to the British Army during the war.

This Book has a detailed description of each unit, describing their abilities and special rules, as well as quick reference tables at the back, covering the various weapons and units available at a glance, and perfect for building army lists from, or for checking stats during play.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Ostfront: Imperial Japanese Armed Forces and Pacific Scenarios
description:
Imperial Japanese Armed Forces and Pacific Scenarios

This book covers the vehicles and forces of the Imperial Japanese Armed Forces in WW2.

From the humble machine-gun nest to the ubiquitous Type 97 Chi-Ha, from the Type 2 Ka-Mi amphibious tank to the 75mm Man-Portable Mountain Howitzer. Every unit a Japanese commander could want is covered, allowing for a wide range of forces to be built.

Also included are 6 brand new Pacific Scenarios, from jungle crawls in dense terrain, to beach landings and banzai charges, these scenarios will give your games a very Pacific Theater feel, and allow you to approximate battles like capturing the air strip at Guadalcanal, or the amphibious landings at Peleliu under heavy fire, or the uphill jungle slog of Okinawa.

The Imperial Japanese Armed Forces covers the 3 main periods of the war; early, mid and late, and covers the evolution of the units over that time. It covers artillery, air support and defense, various light vehicles, 3 types of infantry, and the many tanks and self-propelled guns available to the Imperial Japanese Armed Forces during the war.

This Book has a detailed description of each unit, describing their abilities and special rules, as well as quick reference tables at the back, covering the various weapons and units available at a glance, and perfect for building army lists from, or for checking stats during play.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Ostfront: Chinese Armies of the Second Sino-Japanese War
description:
Chinese Armies of the Second Sino-Japanese War

This book covers the forces available to the armies of China in World War 2. From the humble conscript, to the Vickers amphibious light tank, from the 70mm Gai Liang field gun, to the various types of cavalry. Every unit a Chinese commander could want is covered, allowing for a wide range of forces to be built.

This Chinese army list covers the 3 main periods of the war; early, mid and late, and covers the evolution of the units over that time. It covers artillery, air support and defense, various light vehicles, 3 types of infantry, cavalry, and the light tanks available to Chinese forces during the war.

This Book has a detailed description of each unit, describing their abilities and special rules, as well as quick reference tables at the back, covering the various weapons and units available at a glance, and perfect for building army lists from, or for checking stats during play.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Shipyard: WW2 Ship Design & Combat Game
description:
Shipyard - WW2 Ship Design & Combat

A simple and effective ship design system is coupled with a more granular combat system, allowing you to quickly build a fleet before a game, then test it out in battle.

Shipyard is designed for miniatures of around 1/3000 scale, although 1/1200 would work just as well.
The game is designed for 2 or more players, on a table roughly 6' x 4' in size.
An average game takes around 2 hours, including the time spent designing your ships (around 10 minutes to half an hour for designing, depending on the size of the game).

Ship Building:

Shipyard allows you to build ships of all sizes, from motor torpedo boats, up to aircraft carriers and super battleships. Each basic hull has a number of available "space" points, which can be spent on weapons, sensors, armor, or extras like aircraft, catapults and smoke generators.

Combat:

Shipyard has a unique combat system, aimed at simplicity and a dose of realism. Fog of war and communication are represented: Ships start the game inactive, steaming forwards until they detect the enemy. Once they become active, they can send messages and orders to other ships, and begin to move and attack as they wish. Rules for Gunnery, Torpedoes, Air attacks and defense, submarines, depth charges, evasive action and much more are provided, allowing for a fun yet fairly accurate rendition of WW2 naval combat.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame, World War II

name: Spies Race to Berlin, A Game of War
description:
Spies Race to Berlin, A Game of War is a board game produced just prior to or at the beginning of World War Two. The large board (74 x 49 cm) shows Germany and surrounding countries. Austria and Czechoslovakia have been absorbed into Germany. The free state of Danzig, neutral Hungary and other countries (including Poland) are still independent.

Starting from London players follow various routes to Berlin, crossing numerous countries either by air, sea or land by the roll of the dice. There are detours, delays and short cuts and players throw again on a 6. The first to reach Berlin on the exact throw of the dice is the winner.

—user summary
categories: Children's Game, Wargame, World War II

name: Thorngate Tower
description: An adventure-style tile and dice drafting game, where players compete to satisfy the leaders and stragglers of Thorngate. Players ascend an abandoned tower filled with demonic creatures in this post-apocalyptic fantasy-style game in order to demonstrate that they are worthy of representing the leaders of Thorngate out in the wilderness. Defeating creatures rewards players with faction points, moving them up 1 of 3 tracks. These will then award end-game victory points, depending on which leaders have been satisfied the most! Along the way players will obtain gemstones, artifacts, spells and more whilst also completing contracts to satisfy the local villagers.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Puzzle
mechanics: Action Drafting, Chaining, Contracts, Dice Rolling, End Game Bonuses, Hidden Victory Points, Ladder Climbing, Set Collection, Tile Placement, Track Movement, Variable Set-up

name: Trick Mr. Troll
description:
The elves just spent a warm sunny morning catching fish, turtles, and frogs. They need to return to their village on the other side of the river, but grumpy Mr. Troll won’t let them cross the bridge unless they pay him a toll! The clever elves agree to give Mr. Troll some of what they caught, but only if he can guess what it is. Can they keep him guessing long enough to sneak across the bridge or will Mr. Troll take everything?

In Trick Mr. Troll, 1-3 elves (usually children) work together to get across the bridge while Mr. Troll (usually a parent) tries to stop them. Every round, each elf hides a single fish, frog, or turtle token in their hand and Mr. Troll tries to guess what it is. If his guess is correct, Mr. Troll collects the token. If his guess is incorrect, the elf pawn moves across the bridge. Tension builds as each guess brings either the elves or Mr. Troll closer to victory!

—description from the publisher

name: Wow!スゴロク (Wow! Sugoroku)
description:
Wow!スゴロク (Wow! Sugoroku) is a Japanese roll & move game. Sugoroku is one of the earliest forms of boardgame in Japan.

This game is a simple roll & move game made for young children. The path is made from face-down triangular tiles, to give a varied snaking pathway. Players turn over the tile they land on and follow the instructions (in English). The first player to reach the end wins.
user summary

name: どんでん (Donden)
description:
どんでん (Donden) is a Japanese abstract game for two players, similar to Reversi. The game has three wooden boards with 4x4 grids, and 48 chips marked on one side.

Donden was created through collaboration, born out of a project to see if something could be done using thinned wood from Sagamihara City. The game is packaged in a wrapped sleeve, made of Japanese paper. The chips are stored in the back side of the boards.

The three boards are arranged in a line. The players place two chips each from their supply in the centre, one player using the marked side.

Taking turns, a player either places a chip on the board, looking to attack as in Reversi, by flipping opponent's chips. Or a player may discard a chip and move one of the three boards around (a disturbance), thus causing an attack.

By taking an end board, for example, the player can place it at right angles, making an L-shape. This puts one of their pieces outside their opponent's, causing an attack.

The game ends when one player runs out of chips. The other player gets a final turn. Then the players get a point for each chip they have on the board, plus a point for each chip left in hand (not discards). The player with the most points wins.
user summary

name: Lunar Echoes
description:
Lunar Echoes is a cooperative game where two players will manage their resources and overcome obstacles during a space trip to the Moon and back, trying to gather the artifacts buried by a lone voyager many years ago - how many treasures can you find?

The game will progress through a series of phases and turns, and in each turn, the players will roll their dice and place them in the board and cards in order to manage their ship resources, collect treasures and avoid danger. At each new round, more cards will come into play, and if the players don't use their dice and resources to get rid of them, they will have to face heir hazards at the end of each round.

The game will result in a loss if any of these conditions are met:

The players come back to Earth with no treasures;
If any of the resources is depleted;
If, at the beginning of a round, there are no cards left in the deck when they need to enter play.


If the players collect enough treasures and survive the whole trip, then the team won!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Drafting, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Die Icon Resolution

name: かなコロン (Kana Colon)
description:
かなコロン (Kana Colon) is a Japanese word game using 18 dice showing hiragana (Japanese alphabet). The game has two ways to play. In both games, players roll the dice to get random letter patterns.

For 2-3 players, use the dice to construct words in Japanese in separate block formations.

For 1-4 players, use the blocks to build a crossword style grid.

The designer says the game is experimental.
user summary

name: Action Mayhem Game
description: To collect the six star tokens that make you a winner, you have to compete all sorts of action tasks - from pretending to be a kangaroo or touching your toes to finding a sock or grunting like a pig.

name: Font HUNT
description:
Font HUNT is a Japanese game made in collaboaration with a Japanese font foundry, Fontworks Co. Ltd. In the same way that European language fonts come in different designs (Times New Roman, Gill Sans) and different styles and weights (Gothic, Bold), many fonts are also designed for the Japanese alphabet Hiragana. Fontworks produced a popular commercial font called 筑紫 (Chikushi), which is then produced in various styles and weights.

The game uses a set of tiles which only show a single character あ (A). The tiles are all varied though, because of the variations in the different Chikushi fonts used.

The game Font HUNT comes in three different foil packs. A pack holds 12 tiles with 6 different fonts.

Each pack can be used for the basic game, and each pack has its own game variant. The basic FONTHUNT (フォントハント) game requires players to identify specific tiles by describing certain aspects of the font. "Huh? It sticks out here?" "A little thick here?" "A little bent?" "A little round!". Players can co-operate to try to discover which tile is being described, or have tiles in hand and try to have the other players work out which they hold. The game is intended to be more of an exasperating fun exploration of the nature of fonts, than a competitive challenge.

筑紫ゴシック 青 (Chikushi Gothic Blue) has a blue badge, and the game Font IMPRINT (フォントインプリント).
筑紫明朝 黄 (Chikushi Mincho Yellow) has a yellow badge, and the game Font TONE (フォントトーン).
筑紫書体MIX 緑 (Chikushi typeface MIX) has a green badge, and the game Font MIMIC (フォントミミック).

In Font IMPRINT, players conveys the impression of a font by using similies: "This A looks like Asaoka!" "This A looks like Amoeba!"
In Font TONE, players have to imply the font by use of the tone of their voice.
In Font MIMIC, players have to use hand and body gestures instead of words.

The packs are normally sold separately (quite cheaply), but the publisher has sold them at the Tokyo Game market in a bundle with a bonus set of new tiles.
user summary
categories: Deduction, Educational, Party Game, Word Game

name: パピプペポペロンチーノ (Papipupepope Ronti-no)
description:
パピプペポペロンチーノ (Papipupepope Ronti-no) is a Japanese word game for 3 players only.

The game has decks of cards showing Hiragana for the the sounds Pa Pe Pi Po Pu and the word Ronti-no. Players have to get the right cards in the right order and say out 'Papipupepope Ronti-no' to win.

There is English on the cards, so the game is playable without knowing Japanese.

The designer apologises for an errata in the first edition rulebook.
user summary

name: 迷宮蟻巣 (Meikyū Arisu)
description:
迷宮蟻巣 (Meikyū Arisu) (メイキュウアリス) (Labyrinth Ant Nest) is a Japanese game designed to help children with simple arithmetic.

Players are constructing an ant's nest by laying tiles to connect tunnels under the soil. Each tile has a number of paths, and each branch has a number from 1 to 9.

The players put a starting tile on the edge and a central tile in the middle of the next. Each player draws a tile and tries to place it such that paths join.

Players are trying to place tiles so that the connecting numbers add up to 10. If a player can do this, they say "Thank you! 2+8=10" (or whatever the sum is). But if a player cannot make a connection add to 10, they are not penalised.

The winner is the first player to connect their starting tile on the outside of the board to the central tile.

The designers suggest an alternate for children who cannot add up, so that they need only have numbers match when played.

Alternately, they suggest you play the game in a terrible windstorm.
mechanics: Grid Coverage, Map Addition, Tile Placement

name: X Corps: The Somme 1916
description:
X Corps: The Somme 1916

This two player card game covers the experience of the British X Corps on the first day of the Battle of the Somme, July 1st 1916.

The game follows the course of the pre-battle preparation and the first day of the battle itself. One player is the commander of the X Corps, Lt. General Sir Thomas Morland. The other player is his opponent Lt. General Hermann von Stein commander of the German XIV Reserve Corps.

X Corps builds on the core rules from VIII Corps, the first game in the series, and introduces:


The concept of “No Man’s Land” reflecting its importance to both sides.
The German use of artillery in tactical defence and in support of their counter-attacks.
The British use of counter-battery fire rather than pure area bombardment.
The consolidation of captured trenches against counter-attacks.
Balanced victory conditions for both sides.


The increased chance of the British winning reflects their greater success on the day. Having said that this game sees the Germans unleash the power of their artillery as the British penetrate the German lines and both sides engage in a brutal fight for the trenches.

Contents:


Rules (12 pages).
Set of colour cards (12 pages with 9 terrain, 33 German & 39 British cards).
Set of printer friendly cards (as above but German & British cards are monochrome).
Set of full colour card backs (1 page)
Illustrated examples of play (11 pages)
Quick start guide (1 page)


—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Wargame, World War I
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Hand Management

name: III Corps: The Somme 1916
description:
III Corps: The Somme 1916

This two player card game covers the experience of the British III Corps on the first day of the Battle of the Somme, July 1st 1916. This, the third game in the Somme series, is an extension of X Corps and uses the same rules.
There are no rules with this game and you will need a copy of X Corps to play the game.

The game follows the course of the pre-battle preparation and the first day of the battle itself. One player is the commander of the III Corps, General Sir William Putteney. The other player is his opponent Lt. General Hermann von Stein commander of the German XIV Reserve Corps.

New cards:


British first use of "Smoke" & "Make Haste" across No Man's Land.
British mines at Lochnager & the Y Sap.
German "Intelligence" intercepts and the use of "Tear Gas".


Key game concepts:


The use of “No Man’s Land” reflecting its importance to both sides.
The German use of artillery in tactical defence and to support counter-attacks.
The British use of counter-battery fire rather than pure area bombardment.
The consolidation of captured trenches against counter-attacks.


Contents:


Historical introduction and set up information (6 pages).
Set of colour cards (13 pages: 9 backs, 9 terrain, 34 German & 39 British cards).
Set of printer friendly cards (German & British cards are monochrome).


—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Wargame, World War I
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Hand Management

name: 鯖威張る・サーバー (Saba ibaru: Server)
description:
鯖威張る・サーバー (Saba ibaru - Server) is a Japanese card game using simple mathematics. The title is a pun, Saba Iburu means mackerel, and 'server' in Japanese sounds like Saba.

There is a problem in the computer, not aliens, not a beautiful woman, no, it's a mackerel. A mackerel has got into the system and it must be fixed.

Players use numbers and arithmetic functions, to try to make the target sum in the shortest possible function.

For example, to reach a target of 38:
8*5-2 beats 30+4+4 beats 4*8+5 beats 40-4.
user summary

name: This Hard & Calcined Earth: A card Wargame of World War II
description:
This Hard & Calcined Earth

Set in North Africa during 1940-43 the game is a campaign level card game.
It portrays the broad sweep of events and strategic issues surrounding the famous desert battles in a game that is different each time it is played.

The name is a quotation taken from the beginning of episode 8 of the famous 1973 Thames TV series "The World At War".

The game deals with all the complexities of the historical campaign yet is physically small enough to put it in your pocket and play it down the pub, on a train, or in the garden.
The rules are simple to learn but difficult to master.

With THACE events affect the outcome of the game but you always have some element of control.

The game provides an alternative, feasible history of the North Africa Campaign every time it's played.

It is, in other words, a campaign in your pocket.

Contents:


Rules & Historical Chronology including both colour & monochrome covers.
Designer's notes.
Set of colour cards. A4 version (8 pages with 11 terrain, 20 strategic & 21 operational cards).
Set of colour cards. US letter version (10 pages with cards as above).
Instructions for cutting out the cards.


—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Wargame, World War I

name: Revolution!  Politics during the French Revolution 1789-96
description:
Revolution! represents the problems facing the French State between 1789 and 1796.

It is a game of intrigue which aims to recreate the politics of the Revolution from the reactionary Monarchists, through the moderate Girondins, to the radical and ultra radical Jacobins.
At the end of the game the French Revolution will have settled on a dictatorial pattern of leadership: the very environment that resulted in Napoleon’s assumption of power.

The game takes place in the French National Assembly building. Players represent one of three political factions each composed of a group of famous characters. They must find solutions to the problems of state raised by this turbulent period whilst wrestling one another for political control.

Each political faction, and in the advanced game each character, has their own agenda to promulgate whilst simultaneously denying their opponents power. Like all forms of politics power is exercised by a series of votes. Players may use debate, bribery, bullying and scurrilous accusation to win these votes. To win this game you must be prepared to engage in all of these activities at some point.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Napoleonic, Negotiation, Political, Print & Play

name: XIII Corps: The Somme 1916
description:
XIII Corps: The Somme 1916

This two player card game covers the experience of the British XIII Corps on the first day of the Battle of the Somme, July 1st 1916. This, the fifth game in the Somme series, is an extension of X Corps and uses the same rules.

There are no rules with this game and you will need a copy of X Corps to play the game.

The game follows the course of the pre-battle preparation and the first day of the battle itself. One player is the commander of the XIII Corps, Lt. General Walter Congreve. The other player is his opponent Lt. General Hermann von Stein commander of the German XIV Reserve Corps.

New cards:


British use the Livens' Flame Projector.
British use, and mis-use, of mines.
Germans have less wire & are generally weaker.


Key game concepts:


The use of “No Man’s Land” reflecting its importance to both sides.
The German use of artillery in tactical defence and to support counter-attacks.
The British use of counter-battery fire rather than pure area bombardment.
The consolidation of captured trenches against counter-attacks.


—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Wargame, World War I
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Hand Management

name: XV Corps: The Somme 1916
description:
XV Corps: The Somme 1916

This two player card game covers the experience of the British XV Corps on the first day of the Battle of the Somme, July 1st 1916.
This, the fourth game in the Somme series, is an extension of X Corps and uses the same rules.

There are no rules with this game and you will need a copy of X Corps to play the game.

The game follows the course of the pre-battle preparation and the first day of the battle itself. One player is the commander of the XV Corps, Lt. General Henry Horne. The other player is his opponent Lt. General Hermann von Stein commander of the German XIV Reserve Corps.

New cards:


British have less heavy artillery.
British mines at Tambar & Mametz.
Germans have less wire & more redoubts.


Key game concepts:


The use of “No Man’s Land” reflecting its importance to both sides.
The German use of artillery in tactical defence and to support counter-attacks.
The British use of counter-battery fire rather than pure area bombardment.
The consolidation of captured trenches against counter-attacks.


—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Wargame, World War I
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Hand Management

name: Tempus Quest: Episode 4 – The Degna Job
description:
After making the right connections, the crew manages to secure a contract. Now they need to equip the Tempus and make it happen. Unfortunately, the Dynasty has caught wind of their operation, which is going to make things tricky.

Games in the Tempus series work similarly to roll and write games where players roll dice and use the results to fill in a sheet. In the Tempus System, instead of using dice, players will use the date and time to randomize setup and available actions.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Grid Movement, Network and Route Building, Set Collection, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Wild West Chronicles: Miniature Wargaming Rules for Gunfights in the Old West
description:
Wild West Chronicles

This easy-to-learn and intuitive game system will soon have you simulating gunfights between outlaws, raids alone the Mexican border, Indian ambushes and many other other situations that are typical of the Far West.
These rules include army lists for desperados, Texas rangers, lawmen, outlaws, town-peoples and Indians.
Each model has a points value that depends on his skills and weaponry so you can create well-balanced scenarios that all the players can enjoy.
the use of the table has been reduced to a minimum and the whole system revolves around the addition and subtraction of six-dice.

There are three standard scenarios inside:

the gunfight,
the rescue and
the ambush!


There is also a simple system to help you track the experience of your squads from one gunfight to another.

If you enjoy the wild west setting then this game for You!

—description from the publisher

name: Beyond the Monolith Core System
description:
Beyond the Monolith is a gaming system based on Batman: Gotham City Chronicles Versus Mode.

It's a two player scenarised skirmish miniature game in which each player control its characters using a command board.
On the command board, each character cost more energy to activate as you move left to right down the line. Once a character is activated, they move to the end of the line, boosting their cost to the maximum value should you want to use them again immediately, and decreasing the cost of the other tiles.

Beyond the Monolith aims to separate the game core engine and the universes in which the game will be played. For that purpose, the "Core Box" is not a full game playable by itself but a core game set that include only a basic ruleset and all common components (dices, tokens, ...).

You will need to combine it with an "universe" that will supply the theme, the specific rules, the campaigns, the miniatures and tiles, the maps.
Monolith will provide two way to get universes :

Universe Products : contains everything needed for an universe (ex : Conan, Batman : Gotham City Chronicles, Lord of the ring)
Second Life Products : provide extra components to play "Beyond the Monolith" with an existing miniature game universe [you will need to have or proxy this game miniatures to play] (ex : Zombicide, Cthulhu wars)
mechanics: Action Points, Action Queue, Area Movement, Dice Rolling

name: 銀河大国5th (Regional Colonialism Wars 5th)
description:
銀河大国5th (ギャラクティックパワーズ5th) (Regional Colonialism Wars 5th) is a 5th player expansion pack for the game 銀河大国 (Regional Colonialism Wars).

As well as containing all the material needed to add a fifth player to the base game, the expansion adds a new fifth mother star, the planet Yuhadra, two new unexplored planets, the board of the planet Komebara and the planet Nihon Hogan.

Also, in addition to the rules for 5 people, the 10-year interplanetary war that depicts the interplanetary war that the space government establishment negotiations broke down, There are two variant rules.
user summary

5つ目の母星、惑星ユーハドラと、新たな2つの未開拓惑星、惑星コメバローズ・惑星ニホンホーガンのボード、その他5人プレイするために必要なコンポーネントのセットです。

また、説明書には5人用ルールのほか、宇宙政府設立交渉が決裂した惑星間戦争を描く「惑星間10年戦争」、惑星カツピコセンバの古代文明の惑星脱出を描く「故郷はカツピコセンバ」の2つのバリアントルールを掲載しています。
publisher's summary
categories: Pirates, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Transportation
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Rondel, Worker Placement

name: Sarasota-Opoly
description:
How do you make a game about the great city of Sarasota, Florida?

While it's impossible to include everything, we jammed all the Sarasota we could into this box. It's full of outdoor adventures, family attraction's, rich history, and of course... Myakka River State Park - a little something for everyone! Looking for a fun-a way to experience Sarasota?
Here's a quick idea of how to play!

Buy your favorite SARASOTA properties, increase your rent by collecting City Blocks and trading them in for Keys to the City. Sound easy? Well, add in some traffic jams, property tax and parking fines and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun!

Get your game on!

Choose your token and advance to GO SARASOTA! You may soon be the Mayor... or out of the game for eating too much Lobster Carbonara from Marina Jack!

This is SARASOTA . . . and it's your roll!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Operation Squad Modern War: Skirmish Rules for Wargames Set in the Modern Era
description:
Operation Squad Modern War

Discover history by playing it.

These simple and intuitive rules will help you simulate the combats that engulf modern-day hot-spots like the Middle East.
Inside you’ll find Army Lists for Americans, British and Italians; there are American Marines and Italian Bersaglieri, Republican Guard and Afghan rebels, for a total of eight possible armies!
Each weapon and army has been given a points value to allow balanced scenarios that are also historically accurate.

The use of tables is minimal, and the whole system is based around a handful of six-sided dice.
The rules also contain three scenarios covering typical missions: Recon, Finding documents and Freeing a hostage.

There’s lots of variety to give you hours of fun.

—description from the publisher

name: For God and King
description:
For God and King is the second expansion for from Gilgamesh to Grant.

Badger with a quill is proud to bring you expanded army lists for the era of the pike and the arquebus.

New army lists and unit types allow you to represent the battles of this most bloody age, from Spain to Mesoamerica, and everything between, if one assumes we were heading east.

—description from publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Emu-Hammer: 1920K
description:
New From Badger with Quill, in spite of no one asking for it, Emu-Hammer 1920k.

A game about the famously failed attempt at wildlife control undertaken by the Australian government.

Things this game is not:

Tested for balance.
Historically or Zoologically accurate.


Things this game is:

Pay what you want
Hilarious.


—description from publisher
categories: Animals, Book, Print & Play, Wargame, World War I

name: Glorious Revolution
description:
In 1688 William of Orange landed in England and ousted James II and his court. The more corrupt Chief Justices, lackeys of the old regime, must now escape England taking with them as much loot as they can muster to ensure a comfortable retirement in exile.

Each player takes on the role of a fugitive Judge, their agents roaming across England visit supporters and arrange for shipping of valuable donations to Carlisle ready for their lord’s escape into Scotland.

As the players collect these donations the forces of the Glorious Revolution sweep across England and Wales seizing
properties and detaining any agent or unfortunate Judge that falls into their hands.

A tactical game of greed and treachery as players gather loot, race for safety and steer the revolutionary forces onto their opponents.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Hidden Victory Points

name: Champions Combat System
description:
The Champions Combat System is a rules engine used by a variety of arena combat board games, created by Dan Piché and published by Faceless Publishing. In games using this system, each player controls a champion and a number of associated reinforcement in battle. Players can battle one-on-one or in teams, and the side with the last champion standing wins.

Battles can take place in a variety of environments, each of which offers different challenges and opportunities.

The initial game release will include two boxes, Blood and Magic, and Into the Wild, with each game box containing six champions and their associated reinforcements, as well as two maps with customizable obstacles. The contents of each box can be seamlessly combined with other boxes to offer players greater variety, and plans include multiple expansions to be produced later.

Instead of dice, the Champions Combat System™ uses a unique and intuitive card-based system to resolve combat. The use of cards rewards strategic thinking and careful resource management, while providing each champion with a unique playstyle that captures their abilities and personality. The Champions Combat System™ provides strategic depth without sacrificing intuitiveness, and a new player can learn to play in only a few minutes. Of course, mastering each of the varied champions will take much longer.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Line of Sight, Modular Board, Move Through Deck, Moving Multiple Units, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game, Square Grid, Team-Based Game, Variable Set-up

name: Blenheim to Balaclava: Rules for Warfare in the Age of the Musket
description:
Blenheim to Balaclava

Rules for warfare in the age of the musket with 2mm armies.
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Civic Anarchy
description:
The World is in Total Chaos!

2042, a cataclysm of manmade destruction and natural disasters has put the United States into a state of total anarchy. Players must take up their arms and compete to gain control over the cities of America in an attempt to unite them back under one rule.

Civic Anarchy is a 3X empire building game. Through levying troops, planting and harvesting crops, building structures, and taxing the populace, players gain strength to build armies to take new cities under their wing.
Civic Anarchy uses a stream-lined chit-pull system. When a player’s chit is drawn, that player get actions equal to the number on the chit, but they may only choose one type of action. With several options available, the player must balance between current needs and future aggressions.

Players start with a small army. Through prosperous choices and conquering cities, they can build bigger armies with troop upgrades and strengthen their cities with resourceful buildings.

The player that reaches 10 Victory Points first is the winner.

Civic Anarchy comes with an integrated solo system to control Non-Player Characters with an AI deck, so that it may be played at any player count. The AI deck and flow chart order around the NPC’s, so the player/s may focus on controlling their own units.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Chit-Pull System, Hexagon Grid, Movement Points, Resource to Move, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Feudal Wars: Revised 2nd Edition – Medieval Warfare Rules 1066 - 1404
description:
Feudal Wars: Medieval Warfare Rules Revised 2nd Edition

The second edition covers the period 1289-1494

Rules for 25mm miniatures

Scale:
1 mini = 20 men
1" = 10 yards

Included army lists:


French and Late Burgundian
French Early Italian Wars
Easterlings (Brabant, Ghent, Liege, Flanders and Hanseatic League)
Burgundians
Imperialists
Italian City States
Spanish
English - Late Hundred Years War
French - Late Hundred Years War
English Wars of the Roses
Scots


—description from the publisher

name: Airland War: Modern Armor Miniatures Rules
description:
Airland War are wargame rules for modern armor, built on the framework established by Panzer War (needed).

Airland War is a set of game rules simulating modern warfare using 1/285 scale miniatures.

Since 1982, Airland Battle has comprised the US Army's basic doctrine concerning how to fight the next war. It recognizes the inherently three dimensions of nature of modern warfare. AirLand Battle conceives of a future battlefield nearly anywhere in the world on which the US Army must fight and win.

AirLand War includes rules covering weapons, troops, and vehicles used in most conflicts between 1948 and present. Helicopter and ground support aircraft are thoroughly integrated into play.

Like Panzer War you have a realistic fire game system. Even though 'fire combat' is considered a quantum of fire, you can still engage and destroy multiple targets in a single turn.

Sequence of Play

TACTICAL ORDERS PHASE
COMMUNICATIONS PHASE
MOVEMENT PHASE
Aircraft/Helicopter /Infantry First Movement Segment.
AFV Close-up / Unbutton Segment
AFV Full Movement Segment
AFV Half Movement Segment
AFV Shift Movement Segment
Aircraft /Helicopter/Infantry Second Movement Segment

SIGHTING PHASE (Primary)
COMBAT PHASE
Stationary Fire Segment
Shift Movement Fire / Old Artillery Segment
(Auto Sighting of First Firing Elements Seg.)
Half Movement Fire Segment
Full Movement Fire Segment
Close Assault / New Artillery Segment

SIGHTING FIRING ELEMENT PHASE (Final)
BATTLEFIELD MORALE PHASE
MISCELLANEOUS DETAILS PHASE


—description from the designer
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Variable Phase Order

name: Stations Manned and Ready 2nd Edition: Naval Battles in the Age of Steel – Action off the Crimea 18th November 1914
description:
Stations Manned and Ready - 2nd Edition - Action off the Crimea

A Scenario set for an Action off the Crimea, 18th November 1914

First World War (Black Sea)

This set provides the necessary ship data sheets to fight the above battle.

A copy of Stations Manned and Ready, 2nd Edition, is required to use this product.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame, World War I
mechanics: Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation, Variable Phase Order

name: Draktilian Deception
description:
Draktilian Deception is a 2 player card and dice game, where you take on the role of an elite operative, tasked with stopping the invasion of earth by a deceptive and ruthless alien race, known as the Draktilians.

The game is played over a number of turns until the endgame is triggered. Each player starts the game by selecting a character and taking that character’s mat and a number of tracking tokens, which are used to keep track of rank and stats in the game. A player also has 2 trooper avatars that are used to target adversaries.

Each turn players will roll dice dice to gain combat and command ability or increase their rank, target and attack adversaries or potentially be attacked by adversaries. They can purchase supply drop cards which will give them the ability to increase their attack or defense values and if possible, wound other characters.

Each Adversary a player defeats, will give them rewards, one of which is the alien substance know as Drakshar.
The player with the most Drakshar at the end of the game WINS.

Draktilian Deception uses a balanced combination of luck and strategy to defeat your opponent and win. The dice provide the random element in the game while the purchase and timing of the playing of cards, give the strategic.

name: Oceanus Strategoi: Miniatures Rules for Small Squadron Naval Combat in the Ancient Mediterranean
description:
Oceanus Strategoi, Miniatures Rules for Small Squadron Naval Combat in the Ancient Mediterranean is a set of miniatures rules for naval combat in the ancient Mediterranean.

The rules are aimed at small squadron actions with each player controlling 3 to 5 galleys.

Ships range in size from triakonters (with 30 oarsmen) up to dekeres, though of course most scenarios would involve the much more common triremes, quadremes and quinteres.

Written orders and damage are recorded on a detailed record sheet.

The game can be scaled to fit existing models.

Originally written to use 1/2000 scale models, all distances are given in 'lengths' which correspond the the length of a trireme (roughly 120 feet).

—description from the publisher at Wargame vault
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Paper-and-Pencil, Simulation

name: Bridges Burned
description:
While enjoying ale at a distant tavern you overheard a mysterious old man speak of vast lands of treasure. You rush back to your village to gather a team of adventurers to seek out the treasure. It turns out you are not the only person who heard the old man.

Bridges Burned is an adventure themed game with the objective to be the first to get all of your pawns to the treasure and bask in your glory as the richest in the land. This game is for 2-4 players and game play is approximately 60 minutes.

How to Play - 5 Easy Steps to Learn, Limitless strategies to figure out

One - Roll the movement die and move your pawns
Two - Roll the resource die and collect resources
Three - You may attempt one river cross
Four - You may construct one blueprint card
Five - Draw an event card and perform the action on it

—description from the designer

name: The Armored Fist: Combined Arms Combat in the Second World War
description:
Armored Fist is a rule system for squad and individual vehicle all-arms combat during World War Two.

Suitable for company to battalion-sized actions during the Second World War, this system can simulate both infantry and combined arms operations and give realistic outcomes to combats early and late in the conflict. Simulate the real tactical choices that confronted commanders in every period of the conflict.

Core concepts are

the alternating player turn,
detection,
defensive fire during the active player’s movement, and
unit cohesion.


The figure scale is a single vehicle or squad of infantry, with a turn covering (very) roughly five minutes of combat.
The rules are written to allow hex or map measurement, with one unit of distance equaling 50 meters. Typical scale is 1”=50m as a decent compromise between the scale of micro-armor figures and playing spaces.

Included in this title:

Complete Rule System, including vehicle and equipment charts
Combat Tables
Game Counters and Artillery Templates
Quick Play and Historical Scenarios covering 1939 to 1945


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Some Corner of a Foreign Field: A Tactical Two Pager Simple Squad Level Modern Skirmish
description:
Some Corner of a Foreign Field is a squad level modern combat game for 4-15 models per side. Using just a d20 or two, it models close range infantry firefights on boards from 2x2 to 8x8. Make sure you bring plenty of cover, because if you're hit, there's a good chance you're going down - better to not get seen at all!

Including rules for off-board support, casualties and morale under fire, Some Corner of a Foreign Field is a quick and easy game to get the blood pumping and the bullets flying.

—description from the publisher

name: Stampede: The Card Game
description:
Stampede is a 2-4 player game (best played with 4) pitting animals of The Savanna against each other in a race for survival.

Players reveal race tiles each turn to progress their animal’s journey, while playing Power cards to either further their progress, or hinder other animals from winning.

Stampede is a game where the animals you choose for your race makes a difference, as anarchy reigns supreme: each animal's power cards can be used by anybody, allowing for some crazy combinations.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action/Event, Push Your Luck, Take That, Track Movement

name: Eagle Troop at the Battle of Easting 73
description:
Eagle Troop at the Battle of Easting 73 is a scenario for Modern Armor

The Battle of 73 Easting erupted about halfway through the brief land phase of the Gulf War. American armored forces had entered Iraq and pivoted to unhinge the enemy’s defenses inside Kuwait. Facing them was what appeared to be a well-trained and well prepared enemy - the elite Republican Guard.

The Republican Guard was dug in, defending the territory it trained in often. The Coalition forces were strung out, navigating by compass and GPS. Fog, sandstorms and “oil rain” confused the picture on the battlefield. All of this, on paper, should have given the Iraqis a fighting chance. Instead, by the end of the 26th of February, 1991, the best they had to offer had been annihilated.

This scenario recreates the historical battle. Variants allow you to explore what would have happened if the Iraqis had been better prepared, luckier, or better trained.

This scenario contains:

Historical information on units and deployment suitable for use with any micro-armor system.
Unit statistics and scenario rules for Modern Armor


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: The Battle of Goose Green
description:
Battle of Goose Green is a scenario for Modern Armor

The Battle of Goose Green, 27-29 May 1982

Falklands War: 2 Para vs Task Force Mercedes
Micro-armor (Infantry!) Scenario with statistics and scenario rules for the Modern Armor,

This scenario recreates the historical battle. Variants allow you to explore what would have happened if the British had used tanks or had their lost helicopters, and what would have happened if the Argentines had shown more aggressiveness.

This scenario contains:

Historical information on units and deployment suitable for use with any micro-armor system.
Unit statistics and scenario rules for Modern Armor


With rules and notes for Solitaire play.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: Modern Armor: Five Battles Arab-Israeli Wars
description:
Five Battles from the Arab-Israeli Conflict, scenarios for Modern Armor

These scenarios are based on five iconic armor actions during the Arab-Israeli conflicts, between 1956 and 1982.

Various liberties have been taken with the historical actions to reduce large, complex battles to a tabletop game, and various vehicles have been used that probably were not present together on this particular battlefield, but saw action in the same theatre of war. An example is the inclusion of the AMX-13 in the Operation Kadesh scenario.

These scenarios were included (in condensed form) in the Modern Armor rulebook.

The Suez Crisis — Operation Kadesh
The Six-Day War — Sharon at Umm Qatef
Yom Kippur War — The Chinese Farm
Yom Kippur War — The Heights of Courage
Operation Peace in Galilee — Soultane Yacoub


Each scenarios contains:

Historical information on units and deployment suitable for use with any micro-armor system.
Unit statistics and scenario rules for Modern Armor


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Hannut and Gembloux 1940
description:
Hannut and Gembloux 1940, scenario for Armored Fist

Hannut and Gembloux: the Battle of the Belgian Plain, 12-15 May 1940

Two scenarios recreating the battles between the 3rd and 4th Panzer Divisions and the French Division Légère Mécaniques and the 1re Divison Marocaine.
Hannut, the largest tank battle the world had ever seen, and Gembloux, where the French stood their ground against everything the Germans could throw at them - until the deadly gap opening up to the South, in the Ardennes, forced them to withdraw.

These scenarios contain:

Historical information on units and deployment suitable for use with any micro-armor system.
Unit statistics and scenario rules for Armored Fist


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Battles of Stonne 1940
description:
Battles of Stonne 1940 scenarios for Armored Fist

Battles of Stonne 1940, Grossdeutschland vs the 3e DCr, 15-16 May 1940

Five scenarios recreating the ferocious battle to control the town of Stonne, the first and best opportunity the French had to derail the drive to the Channel.
Infantry Regiment Grossdeutschland faced off against the tanks and soldiers of the 3e DCr and 3e DIM in a battle German veterans would later say was as intense as Stalingrad. Day and night actions, infantry vs tanks, and the rampage by B1 bis commander Pierre Billotte, who claimed 13 kills in one action.

These scenarios contain:

Historical information on units and deployment suitable for use with any micro-armor system.
Unit statistics and scenario rules for Armored Fist


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Assault Platoon: Wargame Rules for Platoon-Level Combat in the Second World War
description:
Assault platoon

This book contains all the rules you'll need to simulate a skirmish-level battle between two enemy armies.
Assault Platoon uses a unique and innovative system to simulate simultaneous actions and reactions that allows you to interrupt or anticipate your enemy's moves.
Assault platoon is a new dimension in miniature wargaming where realism and simple rules are perfectly balanced.

The whole game-system is based on adding and subtracting six-sided dice.

Fast, easy to learn and historically accurate.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Lords & Servants: The Wars of the Roses
description:
The Wars of the Roses is a Lords & Servants supplement dedicated to the Wars of the Roses.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Lords & Servants: Limes – Supplement for the Fall of Rome
description:
Limes is a supplement for Lords & Servants skirmish rules by'Dadi & Piombo and it has been adapted to the second edition of the rules released in 2018.

Lords & Servants is a game system designed to recreate skirmish games with 28, 20 or 15mm miniatures.
It covers the Medieval period and it shares the mechanics of our popular system Smooth & Rifled, that covers the age of musket.

In this supplement you will find all the information that you need to create your games set during the final struggles of the Roman Empire, from simple clashes involving a few men per side to bigger encounters with 60-80 miniatures per side, ideal for multiplayer games.
You can field your force choosing from:

Late Romans,
Huns,
Franks,
Early Ostrogoths,
Vandals,
Visigoths or
Early Saxons.


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Lords & Servants: The 1066
description:
The 1066

Lords & Servants supplement.

Updated version to go with second edition of the rules.

—description from the publisher at Wargame vault
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Mit Hindenburg und Zeppelin nach Amerika
description:
The players start in Frankfurt a. M. and travel either to New York (north route) or Buenos Aires (south route) and back. Movement of the airships is determined by a die. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players. The first player to complete his journey wins the game.

—first edition
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Das Verkehrszeichen Lehrspiel
description:
One player moves an steamengine on the tracks from the train station in front of space 1 to the station after space 135. Up to three motorists move their cars on the streets from the parking lot near space 1 to the parking lot after space 125. Movement is determined by a die. On the roll of a 1 or a 6 the signals on the traffic tower in the center of the game board get changed.
On some spaces traffic situations hinder or benefit the players. The first player to reach his destination wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Patata Burgesa
description:
The Patata Burgesa is a game set in the Medieval Potato universe, where players will have to do everything in their power to secure and maintain the prized "Patata Burgesa" card.

The turn:
During each Round, each player has a turn, during which the player can only throw a card and then the action of the specific card will be performed.

The victory:
When as many rounds as players have been made, the end of the game will be marked, and the player who has the “Patata Burgesa” card, wins the game and rules the Potato-Medieval universe.

—description from the designer

name: Making History
description: Making History is a board game, where two players compete to earn the major amount of points. The game consists in answer historical questions about all the ages, while competing to be the best.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Print & Play, Trivia

name: Le dernier des Mohicans: Il était une fois la Légion
description:
Il était une fois la Légion uses and adapts the rules of Le dernier des Mohicans(a copy is needed) to simulate skimish miniature wargame in the North African Desert between the French Foreign Legion and Arabic warriors (Bedouin, Tuareg...).

for 15-25mm 1/72 minis

Sequence of play:

Fire phase
Movement phase (inc. charges moves)
Reloading phase - for arty only
Mêlée phase
Moral test phase


Scale:

1 cm = 2m
1 mini = 1 individual
1 turn = 1 min


—user summary
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Champions of Akathena: Into the Wild
description:
Champions of Akathena: Into the Wild is an exciting, fantasy combat board game that uses the Champions Combat System™. This complete boxed game contains everything two to six players need to start playing out exciting tabletop battles, including a complete copy of the core Champions Combat System™ rules.

Set in the fantastical, war-torn world of Akathena, this boxed set contains maps for two different battlefields, the Greywolf Forest and the Heartland Mountains. Players will be able to choose from six different champions who hail from these lands, each with their associated reinforcements. The Huntsman and his trusty Wolf are native to the wilds of the Greywolf Forest, as are the Elven Archer and her Snake companion, and the Elven Swiftblade and her Panther ally. In opposition to these deadly hunters, the Shinobi and pair of Genin hail from the Heartland Mountains, as does the eccentric Gnome Alchemist and her two Gunslinger companions, and the Shapeshifter and her pair of pet Savage Cats.

As a Champions Combat System game, Champions of Akathena: Into the Wild seamlessly integrates with all other games built using the same system, including Champions of Akathena: Blood and Magic.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval, Miniatures
mechanics: Action Points, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Hand Management, Line of Sight, Modular Board, Move Through Deck, Moving Multiple Units, Square Grid, Team-Based Game, Variable Set-up

name: Dungeons Of Old
description:
Dungeons of Old is a unique take on a deck-building game for one to four players, in which you take control of your very own ragtag band of adventurers and turn them into a formidable fighting force to take down monsters, snatch up loot and buy new cards on your way to defeat one of FIVE Dungeon Bosses.

Players will start with the same ten card deck, featuring characters, equipment and spells, to enter their first dungeon. There they'll compete with each other to fight, defeat and direct monsters and snatch up more than their fair share of the loot they guard.

The aim of the game is to make more money from your adventuring efforts than the other players at the table and win ultimate glory in defeating the dungeon boss!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, End Game Bonuses, Market, Negotiation

name: Breaking Ball: Gaelic Football Board Game
description:
Breaking Ball is a Sports themed game based on one of the Irish National Sports - Gaelic Football. It is a card and dice game with an emphasis on tactical use of your team players throughout a game.

Each team has 15 'players' in various positions throughout the playing pitch from Goalkeeper to Full Forwards. It follows the proper rules of Gaelic Football.

Each team tries to win possession of the football and beat their opponent in that 'zone' of the playing field before passing the ball via various attacking cards, while their opponent tries to intercept the ball by counteracting their moves with their defending cards.

Once a player gets past their opponent and successfully moves the ball through the playing field zones into their attacking half of the field they can attempt to shoot for a point from long range (using dice, the further out harder it is to score) or they can try and work their way in to shoot for a goal or an easy point, whilst their opponent tries to dispossess them of the ball (by means of card moves). A goal represents 3 points and a point is, well 1 point! (a point in Gaelic Football is kicking the ball over the crossbar and much easier to accomplish than scoring a goal).

Players can get yellow carded and red cards sent off - there are star players on each team with added skills and the tactical element of how you deploy your players can have a big impact on the outcome.

Its a 2 player game (2 teams) but players do join together to manage a team against other opponents.

Tactics is a big part of the game and how you deploy your team and counteract your opponents star players will have a bearing on the outcome.

So game play follows the rules to move up and down the field as each player tries to work their way into a possible scoring zone.

Play in a real game lasts 30 minutes per half but players can decide a time limit. The winner is the player with the highest combined score (goals and points) at the end of the allotted time.
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Different Dice Movement, Grid Movement

name: Flight Time
description:
In the economic game Flight Time, you are an airline company competing with other airlines for customers around the country. You start with a small airplane and a hub city. Throughout the game you'll be trying to: increase the size of your fleet, upgrade your fleet, purchase flight times between two cities, keep your planes fueled, and either rent hangar space for your airplanes that are waiting for demand or reassign your planes to a different route that is more lucrative.

There will be a map of the USA with cities connected to each other by lines. Those cities will have space (hangars) for small plane tokens. Above the connection line will be flight times, which are spaces for tokens to claim to be able to fly the route. Below the connection line will be space for passenger tokens to be placed, showing demand for the route.

When you buy a plane you will receive a small plane board with a number of seats available for passenger tokens to fit into, as well as tracks next to the plane showing fuel status and amenities level this plane is at. In addition, you will have tokens to indicate seats that are upgraded to first class seats, providing more income on your flight.

—description from the designer

name: Fields of Fire: Fast Play Rules
description:
Fields of Fire: Fast Play Rules is the fastest way to get started with the system!

You can be up and playing your first game in under five minutes.

Fields of Fire is a miniatures game for combat from 1975 to present.

For 1:285 scale up to 20 mm minis.
One miniature equals one vehicle.

—user summary

name: Fields of Fire: Crucible of Force
description:
Crucible of Force uses the Award Winning Fields of Fire game engine to bring our fast paced, yet accurate play style to the Second World War.

These rules cover European Theater combat from the beginning of the war to the Summer of 1943.
Also included are play charts and other play aids to make your gaming experience more enjoyable.

The rules cover all aspects of game play, from movement and shooting to command and control, but are written in such a way as to allow the player to design a scenario as simple or as advanced as desired.
Novice players appreciate the easy to understand format, while veterans appreciate a fast-paced game that maintains real-world accuracy for their historical or what-if scenarios.

Playable at either 6mm or 15mm, Crucible of Force allows you to use the scale you prefer for your game.
Each miniature represents 1 tank and infantry basing is flexible.
The game plays as well for platoon level combat as it does for a battalion.
These rules cover equipment from the USA, USSR, Great Britain, France, Poland, Germany, and Italy.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Stars and Crosses: North Africa 1940-43
description:
Stars & Crosses: North Africa is a campaign expansion for Stars & Crosses Revised Edition 1.2, the game of WW2 company-level combat in 6mm scale.

You will need a copy of the core rules to play.

This expansion includes rules for:

dust clouds,
desert terrain,
digging in,
flares,
antitank ditches,
desert hazards, and
sandstorms.


Unit counters are included for

Italian units, plus new
British,
German, and
American units.


Four scenarios are included.

The printables section of the PDF includes

terrain hexes,
markers, and
unit counters.


—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Combat Command: Battalion Level Rules for World War II – Advanced Game
description:
Combat Command - Advanced Game

This addition to the innovative Combat Command system includes the full advanced game and optional rules which allow players to tailor their games to whatever level of simulation detail they wish.

The Advanced Game builds on but does not change the rules from the Basic Game.
The Advanced rules include additional terrain rules, extra capabilities for troops including Engineer, Recon and Anti-Tank.
These rules also expand Commanders capabilities and add new command functions.
New rules also cover National Differences in order to give a unique flavor to the armies fielded by the United Kingdom, the United States, the Soviet Union and Germany.

The optional rules add a new level of simulation detail including rules to reflect the difficulty of using long barreled weapons in urban settings and a complete list of Engineer tasks from digging foxholes to building bridges.

Despite the increased level of simulation detail the system retains the logical and easy to use mechanics of the original game making it ideal for club or convention play. Easy to introduce to new players yet a satisfying and complete game for even the most battle tested World War II gamer.

This section requires a copy of Combat Command - the Basic Game to use.

As an added bonus this packet also includes Saint Lo to the Siegfried line a set of Army Lists covering July to November 1944. These lists allow players to recreate historical Battlegroups in evenly matched battles. In addition a section covers how to create well balanced battles based on actual historical match ups. This section can be used with virtually any platoon based system.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Lifewrecker
description:
Party game for 3-4 players or teams.

On Kickstarter May 5, 2020:
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/3inchhighgames/lifewrec...

Object of the game is to lose health, wealth, and social status on the way to rock bottom.

Players answer questions of how they would handle a scenario. Answers result in penalties (which in this game are a good thing) and advance tokens toward disgrace, destitution, and death. Once a play or team achieves all three objectives, the game is over.

The game takes 20 to 40 minutes to play depending on the amount of team discussion.

—description form the designer

name: Brigadier General: World War II Miniature Rules for the Solo-Wargamer
description:
Brigadier General

An element based World War II miniatures solo wargame with a d6 based system, Regiment & Brigade level battles.
Think of yourself as a Colonel or Brigadier General and that your concern is not so much what individual weapons or tactics a unit has but what its function is within your command.

It is assumed that you are a solo wargamer and that most of the terms in our book will already be familiar to you. Our goal with Brigadier General was to provide a fun and simple game with the ability to cover battles both real and imagined from 1931 to 1958. This is not a complicated game to produce historical results, but rather a simple game with a World War II setting . Remember when reading as well playing our game, to look upon them from the viewpoint of a solo wargamer.

We do not define ground & time scales in our games, instead we opt for what feels right on the table. Brigadier General uses blocks of troops which we call elements vice individual soldiers. Normally elements of troops in Brigadier General equate to a military company or depending on the game/scenario sometimes a battalion. However they can be scaled to suit any battle. Given the constraints in game, each player force would approximate a brigade, combat command or regimental team, hence our game’s name.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Korean War, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: COMBAT: 1948 Arab-Israeli War
description:
COMBAT: 1948 Arab-Israeli War

Wargame rules to create battles of the 1948 Arab-Israeli Wars in 15mm, based upon our Combat WWII game system. D6 based. IGOUGO turn sequence.

Includes:

Tables of Equipment for both Arab & Israeli forces,
Scenarios,
Army Lists for most Arab forces like the Arab Legion, Egypt, Jordan, as well as the Israeli forces.
Features like:
Commandos,
Minefields,
Weather,
Flamethrowers,
Artillery.
Aircraft
and more...



—description from the publisher

name: COMBAT: The American Civil War
description:
COMBAT: the American Civil War

15mm miniature wargame rules for the U.S. Civil War.

Features: Command Phase, Field Hospitals, special abilities like Rebel Yell & special units like Spencer's Rifles.

Multiple figures per base.

D6 based system.

IGOUGO turn sequence.

—description from the publisher
categories: American Civil War, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Adventures with Gun, Sabre & Horse
description:
Adventures with Gun, Sabre & Horse allows you to wargame battles of the late 19th Century in 15mm.

This is the first set in the series and contains the basic core game rules as well as two army lists with sample armies.

The two army lists with the core rules are:

Zulu Impi &
British Colonial Army.


Future expansions will include advance rules, more units, armies and equipment.

Multiple figures per base with a 40mm frontage.
Point based & scenario gameplay.
IGOUGO turn sequence.

This is an "Old School" type wargame with simple yet trusty d6 mechanics.

—description from the publisher

name: Imperium: Rome and its Enemies 107 BC to 476 AD
description:
Imperium – Armies and Enemies of Imperial Rome is the second supplement for the Crusader wargames rules covering the armies and enemies of Imperial Rome.
There are 13 lists enclosed, each with its own background information, army guidelines, allies, special rules and points values.


Late Republican Rome 107 to 27 BC
Early Imperial Rome 27 BC to 117 AD
Middle Imperial Rome 117 to 285 AD
Late Imperial Rome 285 to 378 AD
Foederate Roman 382 to 476 AD
The Barbarians 105 BC to 476 AD
Spartacus’ Revolt 73 to 71 BC
Jewish Revolt 69 to 73 AD
Sarmatian Tribes 250 BC to 370 AD
Parthia 238 BC to 225 AD
Sassanid Persia 225 to 649 AD
Palmyra 250 to 273 AD
Huns 370 to 454 AD


—description from the publisher
categories: Ancient, Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: The Macedonian and Punic Wars
description:
The Macedonian and Punic Wars is the first army list book for the Crusader Wargames Rules.

You’ll need a copy of these rules to gain the most from this supplement but there is enough useful information (and some very nice photographs) to make this a worthwhile book in its own right.

There are seven major armies listed as well as details for allies and mercenaries that can supplement the forces of any of the major powers. As well as the army lists each nation has information on its history and major campaigns and advice on how to organise your forces and get the most from your troops on the tabletop.


Carthaginian 275 - 146 BC
Gallic 400 - 25 BC
Hellenistic Greek 250 - 50 BC
Macedonian Successor 320 - 146 BC
Numidian 300 - 25 BC
Roman 275 - 105 BC
Spanish 200 - 20 BC


—description from the publisher
categories: Ancient, Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Ramasse Trésor
description:
A simple and fast family attention game for pirates!

The game consists of 50 thick round cards, with five elements drawn from the pirate universe (tricorn, long-view, treasure, pistol, bottle, etc.) on one side (yellow background) and one of these elements on the other side (white background). There is also a bomb card.

All players will play at the same time. The cards are spread out on the table facing yellow. At the start, each player takes a card, turns it and places it in front of him facing white. He must now find another card that shows on its yellow face the element discovered. He takes it, turns it on the white face and places it on its stack, revealing a new element to find and so on. When a player no longer has a chance to play, he grabs the bomb. All players check and look at who has picked up the most cards (including the bomb).
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Party Game, Pirates, Real-time

name: Cat'astrophes: promo pack
description:
8 New cards to add to the game.

Pack found in Plato magazine 122.
categories: Animals, Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Party Game

name: POTUS
description:
A family card game simulation of political life and elections in the USA since 1944. Play to become President Of The United States (POTUS).

Each player controls politicians who will run through the election process (primaries and presidential) in the hope to get elected President.

A President will then have to solve crisis, face Congress and maintain his approval by playing Executive cards during the course of his mandate.

Getting elected, playing or solving crisis (cards) will gain you Political Points, the winner being the first to reach 51 or the one who ends the agreed game duration with the highest score.

Players play with Politician cards, both historical and random, and have States cards where the can be elected.

They have access to Supports cards (to gain votes in Elections), Fundraising cards (to finance campaigns), Actions and Campaign cards to play more or less when they want (the "dirty tricks" department), and finallty Crisis cards to impeded the President's actions, opposed by Executive cards to solve the former.

Each turn see a card draft phase, a Congress phase where recruitments and other actions are taken, and an Election phase which allows to get candidates through to the supreme job.

Game has been divided into 3 equivalent periods of 6-7 turns to allow for shorter play. You can play the full campaign from 1944 onwards, till 2020...!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, King of the Hill, Negotiation, Open Drafting

name: Hex-A-Spell
description:
Hex-A-Spell is a hexagonal four-letter word game for your family and for school as a literacy/spelling game.

Connect two-letter bigram fragments to form four-letter words.

In this family word game, the goal is to make four-letter words from two-letter fragments (bigrams) and score top points. Compete with word fragments on hexagonal tiles. Form words in any direction using the most common bigrams in the English language.

—description from the designer

name: Pair Four
description:
Pair Four is a tabletop word game where you make family-friendly four-letter words.

Link pairs of bigrams (two-letter fragments) one the sides of tiles into four-letter words.

—description from the designer

name: Shifters Word Search
description:
Shift letter tiles and find words in this dynamic word search game for one or more players aged five and up.

This lasercut wooden game comes with

50 A-Z letter tiles
game board with 20 gates.


The goal is to shift letters to make and find words in any direction. For solitaire mode, try to beat your highest score shifting 25 letters.

—description from the designer

name: Homeric Hack
description:
Homeric Hack is designed to recreate in miniature individual duels, the epic battles of the Trojan War, from the battle of Thicket Ridge to the sack of the city itself and even the battles Aeneas fought in Italy. Only your imagination sets the parameters of the great engagements you can recreate.
The system allows for heroic duels, large army engagements, naval engagements and sieges with the silver lining being a simple Divine Intervention system.

Homeric Hack Warfare in the Age of Heroes. explores in detail the military conflicts around the time of Homer (circa 800 B.C.). From the individual duels to the legendary battles of the Trojan War, Homeric Hack puts you in the midst of the military struggles immortalized by Homer, Creophylus of Samos, Panyassis of Halicarnassus, and others. Homeric Hack peels away the layers of myth formed over the centuries to reveal Greece's flesh and blood struggles as it blossomed into an ancient-world superpower.

Scales:

1"= 50 feet
1 turn = ~ 20 min
1 mini = 5 to 200 men


Turn Sequence
Optional Challenge
Optional Divine Intervention

Charge & Charge Response
Shooting
Morale Test
Move Charges & Charges Responses
Normal Movement Initiative
Melee
Rally


—description from the publisher

name: Combat Command: Tripoli to Tobruk – Army Lists for Mediterranean Theatre September 1940 - December 1941
description:
Tripoli to Tobruk is a Combat Command supplement covering the Mediterranean Theater of Operations September 1940 - December 1941.
