And finally finally, not forgetting the war-tokens themselves which players can print-off and use in their Grand Ambition games.

—description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Escalade: Mercenary Scum – Seventeenth Century Skirmish Scenarios
description:
Mercenary Scum is a wargame supplement designed to be used with Escalade, the skirmish rules for the seventeenth century. Six scenarios are included in this supplement - with a brief summary below:

Scenario One:


Contributions, a scenario of slash and burn tactics involving a collection of devious and untrustworthy characters - and the enemy aren't too nice either!

Scenario Two:


The Peasants are Revolting, a desperate battle to survive between fleeing soldiers and murderous bands of peasants. Can heroics save the day or will it be better to run, run, RUN!

Scenario Three:


Rescue Rupert, a game of suspicious guards, tough mercenaries and rebel fanatics and a daring attempt to free Prince Rupert from the dastardly clutches of the Emperor.

Scenario Four:


Assault on Bastion 13, an intense and bloody assault on a well-entrenched enemy. Choose your weapons: mortars, grenades, snipers? Can you be the first hero to breach the enemies defences?

Scenario Five:


Escalade, a frantic attempt to break out from the stranglehold of the enemies siege-lines. Will our heroes manage to escape before the enemy (industriously slaughtering civilians) can assemble to foil their escape?

Scenario Six:


Bandit Country, valuable supplies must get through to beleaguered troops, even if this means moving the wagons through this dark and ominously silent wood. But wait a moment, what's that blocking the path up ahead, a fallen tree? Did that tree just fall down, is that the glint of a gun-barrel pocking through the trees? The horses are getting nervous! Are the enemy about to attack...

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: The Danish War: Wargame Supplement for Father Tilly
description:
The Danish War is the third supplement in the Father Tilly series.

It contains army lists, generals profiles and a Lutter battle scenario.
Also in the supplement is a number of sections containing new rules - including rules for Solo gaming and a section showing how players can take 'Father Tilly down to a whole new level - where players can fight "company-actions" rather than massed battles.
This new section allows for an extra layer of detail, including new weapons, hidden movement and skirmish skills for leaders adept in the "dark-arts" of irregular warfare.

In addition to this there is a detailed section on military entrepreneurs - effectively a set of campaign rules where humble mercenary captains can rise to the heights of all powerful Generalissimo's.

There are also a number of new war-tokens for players to add to their decks - so lots more stuff for Father Tilly players to enjoy!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: The French War: Thirty Years War Supplement for Father Tilly
description:
The French War is the fifth in the series of Thirty Years War supplements for Father Tilly.

This period saw the arrival of French armies in Germany and their struggle and eventual success against their rivals the Spanish.
Included in this supplement are extensive army lists for new arrivals and old enemies alike as wells as descriptions of how tactics and formations changed during the period and of course detailed profiles of the leading generals.
The French War also includes two scenario's which provide detailed orders of battle, maps and special rules for the Battles of Wittstock and Jankow - where players can test their abilities against historical outcomes.

The French War covers the last phase of the Thirty Years War, the final and most destructive period of the conflict where religious and political ideals gave way to a gruelling war of annihilation which eventually ended with the Peace of Westphalia in 1648 - more than enough scope for many bloody and hard fought Father Tilly battles...

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: The French Wars of Religion: Bad War Army Lists and Scenarios
description:
The French Wars of Religion is a supplement designed to be used with the renaissance battle rules - Bad War.

The supplement contains army lists and scenarios for the French Wars of Religion and the later Italian Wars.

The scenarios included are for the battles of Ceresole, Dreux and Coutras and include background and terrain details, maps and unit cards detailing the profile of all the units involved.
Also included are a number of new War Tokens. These are the event/action cards that Bad War/Father Tilly players will be familiar with - and these include tokens for capturing enemy standards and dealing out treacherous moves to the opponent - all highly appropriate activities for sixteenth century commanders!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Tudor Warfare: Tudor and Elizabethan Wars Supplement for Bad War
description:
Tudor Warfare is the second supplement for Bad War - the Renaissance battle rules.

As the title suggests, the armies and battles of the Tudor and Elizabethan wars are covered here.
Inside players can find army lists for the Anglo-Scottish Wars as well as details for the Royal and Rebel armies of the Western Rebellion.
Also featured is a French army list to provide opposition for Henry's continental adventures.
There are also details for the armies that fought in Ireland, both native Irish, "Old English" and the English Elizabethan army.

Three scenarios are also included, for the battles of - Flodden, Pinkie and Yellow Ford. These detail the background, orders of battle, unit deployment and maps, and also provide unit cards for all of the participants in the battles.

This period offers players the chance to fight a variety of battles, from the massed conflicts in the open terrain of the Scottish Wars to the smaller more chaotic encounters in the dense terrain of Ireland.
It also takes players from the medieval weapons and tactics at the beginning of the sixteenth century, to the gradual introduction and eventual dominance of the firearm towards the end of the period.
Whichever battles players choose to fight, they will find an interesting, enjoyable and often overlooked period of early modern warfare.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: War on the Eastern Frontier: Father Tilly Supplement for Ottoman, Polish & Muscovite Armies
description:
War on the Eastern Frontier is another gaming supplement in the Father Tilly series.

As the title suggests, this supplement looks at warfare on the eastern borders of Europe, from the "Time of Troubles" to "The Deluge" and provides a detailed look at the Ottoman, Polish and Muscovite armies.

This booklet provides army lists which focus on the troop types, tactics, weaponry and deployment of these new opponents but also looks at the way western armies had to adapt to face these fast moving and ferocious enemies.

Also included in the supplement is a Battle of Kircholm scenario plus a section that allows players to generate numerous - vicious, squalid (but highly entertaining) small-scale scenarios of their own.

Finally, the Eastern Frontier supplement includes a number of new war-tokens especially designed to make these new armies an even greater challenge to play and defeat.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Our Moccasins Trickled Blood: Rules for Gaming the Struggle for the Old Northwest
description:
Our Moccasins Trickled Blood

Tactical skirmish rules for gaming the struggle for the Old Northwest, 1790-1795.

Each figure represents 15 men.
Written for 28mm figures, but can be adapted for other scales.

Fast, easy rules.
categories: American Indian Wars, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Meet the Martin Family
description:
Meet the Martin Family is a board game based on a successful Australian radio series called 'Martins Corner' that run from 1939 - 1955.

The playing board shows 111 spaces where players move by the roll of a dice to reach the Martin Family corner grocery store. First to do so is the winner.

The board game was based on the radio characters and certain special spaces have players move ahead or fall back depend on the romance, adversity or economics of the Martin Family characters. The movement is similar to Chutes and Ladders and is represented by a plane flight.

The game was a premium given away by Kellogg's, who was the major sponsor of the radio program. Interestingly the left and right corners of the game board has the title Kellogg's Aeroplane Flight Game.

—user summary

name: The Disney Derby
description:
Disney Derby is a table top race game where 4 Disney characters are pulled along by cord attached to a winder. The first to the winning line is the winner.

The Disney characters move by sliding along the table whilst being reeled in by the players cord. Each die-cut figure is about 3x3" and are of Mickey, Donald Duck, Pluto and Fifer Pig. The cord is reeled in by a winder that consists of a spool attached to a crank handle which the players rotate as fast and as steadily as they can.

Two versions exist with either a wooden or metal winder. Made in Australia with special permission Walt Disney Micky Mouse (Aust) during the early 1940's.

—user summary
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Ran an den Feind
description:
This is a fleet combat game for 2 players from WWII. The goal is to defeat the enemy fleet and to take the enemy harbor.

Each kind of warship and the forts (pewter guns) have their own characteristics (damage/firing range/movement):

Battleship (4x): d=4, f=3, m=2 straight or 1 curved
Cruiser (2x): d=3, f=2, m=2
Torpedoboat (4x): d=2, f=1, m=3
Submarine (4x): d=1, f=1 emerged or 0 submerged, m=2 submerged or 1 emerged
Forts (4x): d=1, f=3, m= rotation only

Each rotation uses 1 movement point.

Alternately the players move one of their battle units. If an enemy unit is in firing range of 2 enemy units it loses 1 damage point, if it is in range of 3 enemy units it loses 2 damage points and so on. Taken damage is indicated by damage markers of the enemy color. If damage is reduced to 0, the battle unit is destroyed. The positions of submerged submarines are marked by damage markers of their own color.

Each harbor is protected by 6 forts on fixed positions and 15 mines inside the red marked area. Their positions are documented on small cards which the players are keeping secret from each other.

—user summary
mechanics: Grid Movement, Movement Points, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Chaosmos: The Temple
description:
The Temple reimagines Chaosmos for up to 6 players and introduces a replacement set of character boards and a new cardset. There's also alliances and ally powers. Combat is more strategic and interesting; because of new cards and powers there's more decision-making. There's lots of new Traps and a new flip card called the Trust Locker. It lets players to store items to share with their ally, a bit like a storage locker that only has one key and every time you close it, only your ally can open it again.

There's a new Temple Clock with slots for mini-cards featuring randomly-triggered Events. There's also power upgrades for each alien, including the 3 new aliens.

There's an optional fold-out board with 10 planets on one side and 12 on the back. This expansion comes with a complete replacement for the equipment cards, with a clean and easy setup to get you playing the game in only 3 minutes!

—description from the publisher

name: Jackson's Valley Campaign: March to June 1862
description:
The full set of FIVE games in the Valley Campaign Series.

Included are First Kernstown, Front Royal, First Winchester, Cross Keys and Port Republic. Save a few dollars by buying the complete set.

The games comes with a printable game board that can be constructed 3 dimensionally for an impressive realistic feel. Counters, rules and all playing aids accompany the game including a set of tile dice for those of you without any cube dice.

—description from the publisher
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Brothers At Arms: Table Miniature Wargame Rules
description:
Brothers At Arms Table Miniature Wargame Rules

These are the American Civil War rules that allow you to use figures to fight the Brothers At Arms board games. They allow to substitute the counters for figures and use them on a tabletop battlefield. Use the counters to identify the units and their characteristics.

The rules are designed to be as fast as the board games.

Bound Sequence:

Orders
Control Range
Command Roll
NIC Marker
Command Range
Command Roll
NIC Marker
Movement
Units
Formation Commanders
High Level Commanders
Attack
Fire Units
Melee Units
Removal
Remove Markers
categories: American Civil War, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Northern Virginia Campaign: July to September 1862
description:
1862: Northern Virginia Campaign Pack

The full set of THREE battles within the North Virginia Campaign.
The Confederates lead by General Robert E Lee are launching an attack across Northern Virginia against the Union Army under General John Pope.

The games comes with a printable game board that can be constructed 3 dimensionally for an impressive realistic feel. Counters, rules and all playing aids accompany the game including a set of tile dice for those of you without any cube dice.

—description from the publisher
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Seven Pines: May 31st 1862
description:
Seven Pines is the twelfth battle in the series and is the second in our Peninsula Campaign set of 1862.

The Confederates are launching a surprise attack against the Union forces on the south side of the Chicahominy River in a hope that they can defeat this smaller force.

The game comes with a printable game board that can be constructed 3 dimensionally for an impressive realistic feel. Counters, rules and all playing aids accompany the game including a set of tile dice for those of you without any cube dice.

—description from the publisher
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: 1862: Peninsula Campaign – March to July 1862
description:
The full set of EIGHT games in the Peninsula Campaign Series.

Included are:

Williamsburg,
Seven Pines,
Beaver Dam Creek,
Gaines's Mill,
Savage's Station,
Glendale,
Malvern Hill and
Retreat to Harrisons Landing.


Save a few dollars by buying the complete set.

The games comes with a printable game board that can be constructed 3 dimensionally for an impressive realistic feel. Counters, rules and all playing aids accompany the game including a set of tile dice for those of you without any cube dice.

—description from the publisher
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: With Match and Flint: Fast Play Wargame Rules for the European Wars of the Early 18th Century
description:
With Match and Flint are fast play wargames rules for the European wars of the early 18th century.

The actual meat of these rules are only five pages long and are intended for a smooth, straightforward and fast paced battle.

However it is intended that critical decisions are required throughout, either with a surfeit of command points or through the lack of them!

You cannot always depend on the reliability of all of your units, but may be surprised when some out perform their betters.

These rules are designed for any figure scale and any basing system to refight the battles of the Spanish War of Succession and the Great Northern War.

—description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Death Derby: Nature's Rage Expansion
description:
Nature is coming for you.

This expansion requires the Death Derby: A Post-apocalyptic Card Game Core Deck.

Nature is coming for you in the first Death Derby expansion that introduces weather effects to expand your tactics and take on multiple opponents at once. These 35 cards bring Nature's Rage to your Death Derby game and leave your opponents scrambling to survive.

—description from the publisher
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Racing, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Race, Track Movement

name: Death Derby: Dangerous Ground Expansion
description:
Take the high ground against your opponents in this Death Derby expansion that introduces track section powers to make your derbies more deadly.
This 39 card set brings Dangerous Ground to your Death Derby game and turns everyone's strategy on top of its head.

—description from the publisher
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Racing, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Race, Track Movement

name: Cold War Tanker: A Cold War Supplement for TFLs "What a Tanker"
description:
Cold War Tanker is an expansion of the Too Fat Lardies What a Tanker game.

It brings the game into the 1980s cold war by including Anti Tank Missiles, LAW toting infanty with their vehicles as well as platoon movement for the Warsaw Pact.

Of course you need vehicle stats and there are stats for the Russian, US, West German and French vehicles, 43 in all.

It keeps the simple fast play spirit of the original game so helicopters are not included.
There are very optional rules for infantry vs infantry combat, ERA armor and side skirts.

What a Tanker is required for this supplement.

It is graphics free, printer friendly except for the title page. All proceeds will go to my local food bank.

So if you ever wanted to face hordes of Russian tanks coming over the border; here is your chance!

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: A Murderful Knight: A Murder Mystery Party
description:
A Medieval Murder Mystery Party! This is a LARP style game where 12-20 guests receive a character to play, complete with secrets, motives and personal goals. Early on one person is murdered (pre-determined) and one person is the murderer!

2-3 hours to play
12-20 guests

You objective: don't get caught and don't get murdered!

—description from the publisher
categories: Bluffing, Deduction, Medieval, Murder/Mystery, Party Game, Renaissance

name: Barbarossa: Kicking in the Door... – Germany Invades the Soviet Union
description:
Barbarossa – Kicking in the Door… is a wargames campaign covering the German invasion of the Soviet Union between June and September 1941.
It is designed for games in which a stand represents a platoon, such as Blitzkrieg Commander, Command Decision: TOB, A Fistful of Tows, Rapid Fire and others, including those which wargamers may have written themselves.

The system generates 150+ hours of gaming spread over 50+ individual battles which are fought over fifteen weekly campaign turns. Bookkeeping is kept to a minimum as players take command of four of the German panzer divisions spearheading the invasion or the Soviet tank and infantry forces opposing them. Straightforward German attacks will be interspersed with Soviet counterattacks, storming city outskirts, holding bridgeheads or trying to break through the fortifications of the Stalin Line. Each type of battle has its own terrain specifications, victory conditions, set up restrictions and likely opposition. Individual battles are reinforced regimental/brigade sized, with some battalions of each division selected to fight whilst others are rested.

In addition to managing the individual battles, however, the German player also needs to manage the campaign. Ever increasing Soviet resistance needs to be curtailed by encircling their forces. Such encirclements reduce the availability of ‘mobilisation points’ which the Soviet players use as currency to ‘buy’ greater or better equipped forces and fortifications with which the slow the German advance. A rapid, deep advance, however, will exact a heavy toll in attrition. Supply will also become a problem for the German players, limiting the numbers they can commit to battle and their artillery/air support.

The book also includes

a brief history of the campaign
background information (such as time and groundscale) useful in adapting the system to different sets of rules and some suggestions for additional optional rules
a system for generating table layouts for individual battles
a comprehensive set of Appendices covering
the Tables of Organisation and Equipment to both platoon and company level for all divisions and regiments involved
42 colour terrain squares to assist in creating the terrain for individual battles
a worked example of the terrain generation system
a Campaign Quick Reference Sheet
an example Campaign Turn
a complete set of very quick play rules
a full colour A4 Campaign Map



Barbarossa – Kicking in the Door… is an ideal campaign for a club (with eight of more players for twelve or more three hour sessions) or one to be organised remotely, by e-mail, with shorter options available for fewer players or those with less time available.

For those who have purchased the author’s previous book of eastern front scenarios (Grey Steel, Red Storm – available on Wargame Vault) please note that around seven pages of history and background from that book are reproduced largely unchanged in Part One of this volume.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: The War That Never Was: A Strike Legion Planetary Operations Module
description:
May 1, 1989: The world goes to war as Soviet forces lead the Warsaw Pact armies against the defenders of the West. The war was brief, brutal, and nearly destroyed the developed world.'

Or, it could have - had it actually happened.

Step into an alternate past to play out battles from The War That Never Was on a brigade and divisional level. This Strike Legion: Planetary Operations module includes:

New rules for engineers (including bridging, bridge demolition, vehicle recovery, and in-game construction of fortifications), scouts, anti-tank detachments, rocket artillery, and more (each of which can be adapted to any Planetary Operations game or setting);
Special rules specific to both NATO and Warsaw Pact armies to better capture the feel of commanding these forces;
Force lists and Data Cards for operating the armies of the United States, West Germany, United Kingdom, Canada, France, Greece, Turkey, Denmark, Soviet Union, East Germany, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, and Hungary on your tabletop battlefields;
Five scenarios and one campaign game highlighting the action of World War Three from Denmark to the Dardanelles;
Additional units and force organizations that allow players to alter the time or location of the war with more modern equipment and formations not highlighted in the scenarios.


History awaits your decision...

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Variable Player Powers

name: WBE: Whole Brain Exercise
description:
Whole Brain Exercise is won by answering more clues on a crossword than your opponents. points are scored based on word length and the number of letters that you add.
Clues to the cross words come in 9 types
Anagram - letters to the answer are in the clue just in the wrong order
Hidden word - word is in the clue may span words
Charade - solution to the clue gives the answer in parts
Reversal - as per anagram but the word is in reverse
Homophones - answer is pronounced in the clue
Two definitions - one word corresponds to both parts of the clue
Container - word is broken into multiple parts. one part is containedin the other part.
Deletion - gives clues of letters to remove from the clue in order to give a hidden word
Exchange - clue is in two parts with the last part being last in the clue.

—user summary

name: Trivial Pursuit The Music Master Game: Family Edition – Cassette Version
description:
99 Fabulous excerpts from the chronicles of modern history and the word of music have been brought together to produce the ultimate music and general trivia quiz - ever.

A Cassette version of the original trivial pursuit.

—user summary

name: Changing rooms: The Card Game
description:
Fancy yourself as an interior designer?Well the race is on against the opposing team to redesign your room. With multiple options on location and decor a £500 spending budget limit and the occasional mishap, your team will need to work together and have a keen eye to win. Enjoy hours of fun with this fast and easy to learn game for any number of players.

Players are divided into two teams and each team is dealt 18 cards these represent the room that need changing. Both teams roll the die to decide the type of room that it needs to be changed into. Teams take turns on a turn a team can take a card and discard one or roll the die and perform an action.
Team wins by having 15 furniture, 3 complementary colour cards which value under £500.

—user summary

name: Chatter Box: The good news bad news game
description:
Game is won by the last player left in the game.
The game is started by a person reading out a piece of good news from the card and throwing a bean bag to another player. This person must reverse the news (from good to bad or visa versa) and throw the sack to another person. Player is out of the game if they hesitate. there statement is too long, the statement is not relevant to the last statement or is a repeat.

Play is limited to time or number of rounds

—user summary

name: Whuppin' Jonathon: Recreating the War of 1812 in Miniature
description:
The Napoleonic Wars are in full swing...

The familiar sight of long lines of scarlet-coated British infantry advance on their enemies, ready to shatter them with their disciplined volleys...

But wait. The opposing soldiers are in line, not an attack column. Some of them wear grey, not blue, and they speak English, albeit with a strange accent.

French-speaking troops are on the British side, decked in distinctive "habitant" dress. On the flanks, buckskin-clad frontiersmen face off against painted Natives, both using tomahawks and scalping knives rather than bayonets.

These are not the ordered fields of Europe. This is the wooded wilderness of North America, where artillery pieces are a rarity and cavalry almost non-existent. Welcome to the Anglo-American war of 1812. It's Napoleonics, but not as you know it...

A complete ruleset for recreating the War of 1812 on land in miniature, Whuppin' Jonathon allows you to refight the small-scale but desperate battles that saved Canada and established the United States as a respected world power.

Use of d10 dice exclusively.

Rules for infantry, cavalry, guns, howitzers, and rockets. Sample battle to illustrate the game - the battle of Frenchtown. Includes an easy to follow ready reference sheet.

—description from the publisher

name: Whuppin' John Bull: Recreating the War of 1812 in Miniature
description:
The Napoleonic Wars are in full swing in Europe...

Meanwhile, in North America, blue-clad American troops face off against savage Indians armed with tomahawk and scalping knife.

But wait. The Indians are on foot, not galloping around on horses. And they have help. They have cannon, and cavalry, and disciplined scarlet-clad British infantry. On the flanks, American frontiersmen in Buckskin face off against Canadian militia in green, black or brown.

These are not the ordered fields of Europe. This is the wooded wilderness of North America, where artillery pieces are a rarity and cavalry almost non-existent. Welcome to the Anglo-American war of 1812. It's Napoleonics, but not as you know it...

A complete ruleset for recreating the War of 1812 on land in miniature, Whuppin' John Bull allows you to refight the small-scale but desperate battles that established the United States as a respected world power.

Use of d10 dice exclusively.

Rules for infantry, cavalry, guns, howitzers, and rockets.

Sample battle to illustrate the game - the battle of Malcolm's Mills.

Includes an easy to follow ready reference sheet.

—description from the publisher

name: Eagles, Swords & Bayonets
description:
Eagles, Swords and Bayonets covers the period from 1790 to 1815 in Europe and Russia. The intent of these rules is speed of play and while trying to return the grand tactical flavor of the Napoleonic Wars.

ln the past we have played many rules for the Napoleonic period and have found them floundering just as the heat of the battle was getting interesting. Red tape, too many odd rules, all in the name of the realism. it is just too unbelievable for gaming.

So what we have done here, is sort through all the good, the bad and the ugly of all the rules we have played, and tried to come up with a set that will stay together when the real fighting starts.

Many rule sets have good qualities about them. What we have done here is try to take all those good thing and make a grand tactical miniature wargame out of them for 15mm to 20 mm figures. With little difficulty one can adapt these rules to fit 6, 10, 25, 30 or 40 mm figures.

The rules are for grand tactical division and corps play although there is no reason you cannot use them for tactical regimental level games.
Players do not need tons of dice just a few D-10 and D-6 dice will do. There is no writing of rules and most games can be played in three to four hours with resolution.

—description from the publisher

name: Panzer Truppe: Armor Combat in World War II
description:
Does this Entry need to be Deleted???
It appears to be a duplicate of:
https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/28715/panzertruppe-armor...

PanzerTruppe is a set of rules for gaming World War II tank battles with miniatures (1/300 through 1/200 scale).

The basic rules comprise only a few pages of text.
Scale:
1 mini = 1 vehicle
1 infantry bases = 1 squad

Optional rules are provided for advanced play involving:

infantry,
anti-tank guns,
artillery,
mortars,
air support,
minefields,
indirect fire,
hedgerows,
hidden set up,
and more.


Specifications are provided for more than 200 armored fighting vehicles covering all major nationalities from 1939 through 1945.

The book includes text, diagrams, vehicle statistics, Quick Reference Sheets and templates.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Game Noir
description:
Become a hard-boiled private eye,
navigate through the dangerous "noir" world,
and find your destiny - maybe even your femme fatale!

In Game Noir, players become private detectives and have to decide wisely what to do with their action points as they move along the NOIR path. Unpredictable events occur there, the detectives may encounter the femme fatale, end up in the bar for a while, or chase the suspect. They gather black and white tokens they can use to cancel effects of unfavorable events. The tokens also determine to which final path (peace, justice, revenge) a player goes. Then they roll dice and earn victory points for achieving various endings (beware, death is one of them). Being the first to achieve an ending, having an alliance with the femme fatale and/or catching the suspect gives the players bonus points.

Printed components are: board (A4 or A3 format) and 80 tokens (2x A4). Rules have 4 pages. Additional components needed are: different-colored pawns (2-5 for detectives, 1 for femme fatale, 1 for a suspect, 1 spare pawn if possible) and 1-2 six-sided dice.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Events, Income, Lose a Turn, Minimap Resolution, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Ziteria: Ziterion's Magic Tournament
description:
Ziterion's Magic Tournament is a game that requires two or more players to start and theoretically speaking, there are no player limits.

Players lead a small elite unit of brave heroes through Ziterion's tournament arena, which he has created in dark underground caves. This means, whatever is located outside the playing field modules is impenetrable rock. Each player tries to pilfer an artifact from the central room of the arena, while fighting off your opponents, and move it to the starting room of the player on his or her left.

As a result, players build stairs to overcome individual levels of the arena, erect walls to block their opponent's path, find and use magical tools that may benefit them, and engage in battles with opponents, or even temporarily join forces with one of the other players in order to defeat a seemingly all-powerful opponent.

In the end, however, only one team can win Ziterion's Magical Tournament.

—description from the designer

name: Fortunes Won and Lost
description:
Fortunes Won and Lost allows you to adventure during the Age of Imperialism^.
Explore the dark recesses of a steamy jungle. Lead a raid against enemy tribesmen. March in relief of a surrounded outpost. You can do this and more with Fortunes Won and Lost.

Why limit yourself to playing only historical games? This is a great period to make up your own countries and places to explore. ImagiNation gaming they call it. Draw up a rough map and put in a few villages. Toss in a fort or two and you’re good.

Inside you’ll find:

Six Army Lists that can be adapted for any army of the Colonial Period.
Rules for combat that work just as well for small skirmishes or big battles.
A complete and easy to track campaign system to give meaning to your games.
A variety of pre-generated games.
A low bookkeeping system to track how well you are doing.
Retirement rules to determine how you ended up after your career has ended.
All this and much more.


Fortunes Won and Lost is an easy game to play, learn and teach. It’s easy, but it’s also fun. It’s easy, but it’s also a challenge. It’s great for when you want to spend less time setting up a game and more time playing it.

While all games “can” be played solo, although not always very well, Fortunes Won and Lost is designed for solo play or on the same side with your friends. The Artificial Intelligence creates a realistic enemy for you to fight where no two games will ever play the same. Welcome to…

FORTUNES WON AND LOST!

^The Age of Imperialism was the period between 1870 to 1914 that saw no less than eight European powers in conflict with each other and the native peoples that inhabited the lands of Africa and Asia to which these powers laid claim”.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Role Playing, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Realm Lords: For castle and country!
description:
The board game where you battle against the other Lords to spread your domain! Whether you choose to be defensive and build your castle one wall at a time or grow your army to control the area’s resources, your goal is to use your army of Archers, Foot Soldiers, Cavalry and Catapults and defeat the other would-be Lords to rule the realm!

Basic game contains full country battle field board, 32 miniature army pieces, 16 castle pieces, scenario card deck, resource tokens, army base counters and more – Over 150 pieces! Special: Contains unique turn/season dial – keep track of player turns and automatically move through the seasons!

Players choose one of four sides for your home township, North, South, East or West. Play as all humans or play as one of 4 additional races with the Race Add-On - Elves, Dwarves, Orcs or Undead. The four corners are reserved for the areas to find one of four resources; Ore Deposit (Iron), Forest (Wood), Granite Quarry (Stone) & Wild Game (Leather). The exact resource located in each corner is randomly determined once the players have chosen their sides. Players may need to decide early on if they will build offensively first by growing their army with iron, wood and leather, or build their castle with stone and wood. Your ultimate goal will be to build an army to overtake all of your opponents and rule the realm! The scenario card deck lets random encounters and events occur - Mercenaries could join your army or bug-infested logs means the loss of critical wood tokens.

Over 150 pieces, cast and printed in sturdy polyurethane/resin in 5 colors, depicting pieces of your castle and your army of Archers, Foot Soldiers, Cavalry, Catapults (2 each of all, per army) and more. As you grow your troops you add base counters to each army miniature to show the size of your force. Battle for the realm’s resources and take down your enemy’s castle. Easy to play and quick to set up – the 24”x 24” game board consists of nine 8”x 8” boards with a handy tray to keep all of your resource tokens and troop base counters separate. 24 dice (12 each of 2 colors) included!

Solo play with the 42 card AI deck and separate rules included. Kickstarter launches 2/13/20

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Player Elimination

name: 中國霸業5000年 (5,000 Years of Chinese Domination)
description:
Monopoly variant in which players attempt to collect various properties and not go bankrupt from paying rents.

"Properties" are named after Chinese dynasties.

All text is in traditional Chinese.

Packaged in a plastic case similar to those used for video tapes.

Published in Taiwan, Republic of China.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Income, Lose a Turn, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Track Movement, Trading
publishers: Little Giant Stationery Business Co., Ltd.

name: The Golden Pyramid
description:
The Golden Pyramid is a card driven game, where the players use colored cubes and tiles to collectively build a three-dimentional pyramid.

The unchilded emperor needs a worthy successor to his throne. He declares that the nobles shall together build a golden pyramid. The emperor demands a pyramid that consists of four levels, with the upper levels being build upon colorful artistic colonnades. The one whose contribution impresses the emperor the most will become the new emperor.

How to build a pyramid:

The cubes in this game represent the columns of the pyramid and are bought by playing a card. The number or cubes a player may draw from the bag is determined by the value shown on the card. Cubes can also be obtained from a common market or by trading with other players.

To actually build a part of the pyramid the players need four cubes (second level or higher) and a card that shows the symbol of an available tile as well as a value that equals at least the level that should be build.

Players mainly gain victory points by building tiles and placing cubes adjacent to already placed cubes of the same color.

The Golden Pyramid was one of two Gold Winners of the 2019 Contest X for the Green Box of Games. In order to play the game the Meeple Mini Expansion or replacements (20 white 10mm cubes, 20 black 10mm cubes, a drawbag and e.g. meeples in player colors) are needed.

name: Battle Games for Renegade Scout
description:
Welcome to the Battle Games pack for Renegade Scout.

With this pack, you receive a full set of rules for standardized games, perfectly suited for pick-up games or for those nights where the imagination is running a little short.

The system includes

standardized set-up rules,
6 missions to play,
victory point system (with handicap rules) and
simple, easy-to-use rules to turn the game into a campaign or a league.


Several options are included to tailor the game to your own experience of course.

Players who cut their teeth on the venerable 2nd edition of Warhammer 40K should feel right at home with this setup.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Timun Mas
description: Timun Mas runs to get out of the woods as quickly as possible, but Buto Ijo is behind her. Based on the Indonesian legend of the young Timun Mas, the game Timun Mas will make you live an unprecedented adventure through three exciting game modes: solo, co-operative and semi-cooperative.

name: The Journey to Tianzhu
description:
Chinese and English game based on the Chinese national epic novel Journey to the West.

Players move their monk, monkey, pigsy and Shaseng pieces from Chang An to Tianzhu (the ancient Chinese name for India) with rules similar to those of Pachisi. Play is made more interesting by inclusion of special powers for each type of piece which can affect each other type in special ways as well as cloud paths which a player may attempt to use to evade his enemies. There are also variant rules to change the victory conditions or play of the game.

Pieces are plastic with colored stickers with the board made from laminated paper.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Napoleon's Grande Armée 1808-1815
description:
You can build Napoleon's French armies between 1808-1815 using Napoleon's Grande Armée Parade Handbook for Grand Battles Napoleon.
In this supplement you will find in-depth divisional organisations for all the French main battle divisions between 1808-1815.
From these lists you can build pretty much any French corps that fought in Spain, Italy, Austria, Russia and Germany. Although for all allied divisions you will need their handbooks as well, as this supplement only covers the French.

Build Line, Reserve, Marie Louise, Marine, Swiss, Grenadier, Young, Middle and Old Guard infantry divisions. You can also build historical Light, Dragoon, Cuirassier and Guard cavalry divisions as well as deploy Grand Batteries.

We have also added in our selection of National Heroes into the Headquarters options. Napoleon comes to mind - naturally! However you can also select Ney, Davout, Lannes, Massena, Soult, Macdonald and Nansouty. Men like Murat and Eugene, who also commanded other national forces will be highlighted in those handbooks. Both of these French Generals will be found in the Armies of Italy handbook. All national traits and special rules pertaining to the French are easily located in the glossary at the end of the book, so you will never have to worry about trying to find out what Marie Louise troops can and cannot do!

Vive la France! Vive l'Empereur!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Wellington's Armies
description:
Third Grand Battles supplement has now been released! You can build British, Spanish, Portuguese, KGL, Hanoverian, Brunswick, Nassau, Netherlands and Emigre armies using Wellington's Armies Parade Handbooks.

The army list building options are very flexible and clearly laid out. Using these lists you can pretty much build any Revolutionary, Peninsular and 1815 historical army organisation using any of these nine nations. Perhaps you are looking to build a 1st Coalition Iberian army composed of Portuguese and Spanish to fight those dastardly French Revolutionaries during the War of Rousillon or maybe mix in some British and Emigre's for a Toulon campaign. Alternatively, a British expeditionary force to Egypt, a British, Spanish or Portuguese force in the peninsular or a glorious British-Allied army to drive back Napoleon from the ridges at Waterloo. Whatever you decide it can be done with this book.

Such a glorious celebration of Wellington's overwhelming influence upon the wars and national armies he commanded, besides his own British redcoats, would not be complete without a few national general options such as Wellington, Moore, Crawford, Forbes, Prince of Orange and the Duke of Brunswick to name a few. Oh and to round the whole book off what better way to celebrate Wellington's Armies than a recipe for Beef Wellington to be made for your next Waterloo game!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame
